Automatically enable the apps in [](#opt-services.nextcloud.extraApps) every time Nextcloud starts.
If set to false, apps need to be enabled in the Nextcloud web user interface or with `nextcloud-occ app:enable`.

This is useful when nextcloud's domain is not a static IP address and when the reverse proxy cannot be bypassed because the backend connection is done via unix socket.

enable.description:
### option `services.nextdns.enable`
Whether to enable the NextDNS DNS/53 to DoH Proxy service.

*Type:* boolean

### option `services.nextjs-ollama-llm-ui.enable`
Whether to enable Simple Ollama web UI service; an easy to use web frontend for a Ollama backend service.
Run state-of-the-art AI large language models (LLM) similar to ChatGPT locally with privacy
on your personal computer.
This service is stateless and doesn't store any data on the server; all data is kept
locally in your web browser.
See https://github.com/jakobhoeg/nextjs-ollama-llm-ui.

Required: You need the Ollama backend service running by having
"services.nextjs-ollama-llm-ui.ollamaUrl" point to the correct url.
You can host such a backend service with NixOS through "services.ollama".
.

*Type:* boolean

hostname.description:
### option `services.nextjs-ollama-llm-ui.hostname`
The hostname under which the Ollama UI interface should be accessible.
By default it uses localhost/127.0.0.1 to be accessible only from the local machine.
Change to "0.0.0.0" to make it directly accessible from the local network.

Note: You should keep it at 127.0.0.1 and only serve to the local
network or internet from a (home) server behind a reverse-proxy and secured encryption.
See https://wiki.nixos.org/wiki/Nginx for instructions on how to set up a reverse-proxy.


*Type:* string

ollamaUrl.description:
### option `services.nextjs-ollama-llm-ui.ollamaUrl`
The address (including host and port) under which we can access the Ollama backend server.
!Note that if the the UI service is running under a domain "https://ui.example.org",
the Ollama backend service must allow "CORS" requests from this domain, e.g. by adding
"services.ollama.environment.OLLAMA_ORIGINS = [ ... "https://ui.example.org" ];"!


*Type:* string

package.description:
### option `services.nextjs-ollama-llm-ui.package`
The nextjs-ollama-llm-ui package to use.

*Type:* package

port.description:
### option `services.nextjs-ollama-llm-ui.port`
The port under which the Ollama UI interface should be accessible.


*Type:* 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

jvmOpts.description:
### option `services.nexus.jvmOpts`
Options for the JVM written to `nexus.jvmopts`.
Please refer to the docs (https://help.sonatype.com/repomanager3/installation/configuring-the-runtime-environment)
for further information.


*Type:* strings concatenated with "\n"

listenAddress.description:
### option `services.nexus.listenAddress`
Address to listen on.

*Type:* string

listenPort.description:
### option `services.nexus.listenPort`
Port to listen on.

*Type:* signed integer

package.description:
### option `services.nexus.package`
The nexus package to use.

*Type:* package

user.description:
### option `services.nexus.user`
User which runs Nexus3.

*Type:* string

debug.description:
### option `services.nezha-agent.debug`
Whether to enable verbose log.

*Type:* boolean

disableCommandExecute.description:
### option `services.nezha-agent.disableCommandExecute`
Disable executing the command from dashboard.


*Type:* boolean

enable.description:
### option `services.nezha-agent.enable`
Whether to enable Agent of Nezha Monitoring.

*Type:* boolean

extraFlags.description:
### option `services.nezha-agent.extraFlags`
Extra command-line flags passed to nezha-agent.


*Type:* list of string

package.description:
### option `services.nezha-agent.package`
The nezha-agent package to use.

*Type:* package

passwordFile.description:
### option `services.nezha-agent.passwordFile`
Path to the file contained the password from dashboard.


*Type:* null or string

reportDelay.description:
### option `services.nezha-agent.reportDelay`
The interval between system status reportings.
The value must be an integer from 1 to 4


*Type:* one of 1, 2, 3, 4

server.description:
### option `services.nezha-agent.server`
Address to the dashboard


*Type:* string

skipConnection.description:
### option `services.nezha-agent.skipConnection`
Do not monitor the number of connections.


*Type:* boolean

skipProcess.description:
### option `services.nezha-agent.skipProcess`
Do not monitor the number of processes.


*Type:* boolean

useIPv6CountryCode.description:
### option `services.nezha-agent.useIPv6CountryCode`
Use ipv6 countrycode to report location.


*Type:* boolean

extraConfig.description:
### option `services.nfs.extraConfig`
Extra nfs-utils configuration.


*Type:* strings concatenated with "\n"

settings.description:
### option `services.nfs.idmapd.settings`
libnfsidmap configuration. Refer to
<https://linux.die.net/man/5/idmapd.conf>
for details.


*Type:* attribute set of section of an INI file (attrs of INI atom (null, bool, int, float or string))

lockdPort.description:
### option `services.nfs.lockdPort`
Alias of {option}`services.nfs.server.lockdPort`.

*Type:* null or signed integer

createMountPoints.description:
### option `services.nfs.server.createMountPoints`
Whether to create the mount points in the exports file at startup time.

*Type:* boolean

enable.description:
### option `services.nfs.server.enable`
Whether to enable the kernel's NFS server.


*Type:* boolean

exports.description:
### option `services.nfs.server.exports`
Contents of the /etc/exports file.  See
{manpage}`exports(5)` for the format.


*Type:* strings concatenated with "\n"

extraNfsdConfig.description:
### option `services.nfs.server.extraNfsdConfig`
Extra configuration options for the [nfsd] section of /etc/nfs.conf.


*Type:* string

hostName.description:
### option `services.nfs.server.hostName`
Hostname or address on which NFS requests will be accepted.
Default is all.  See the {option}`-H` option in
{manpage}`nfsd(8)`.


*Type:* null or string

lockdPort.description:
### option `services.nfs.server.lockdPort`
Use a fixed port for the NFS lock manager kernel module
(`lockd/nlockmgr`).  This is useful if the
NFS server is behind a firewall.


*Type:* null or signed integer

mountdPort.description:
### option `services.nfs.server.mountdPort`
Use fixed port for rpc.mountd, useful if server is behind firewall.


*Type:* null or signed integer

nproc.description:
### option `services.nfs.server.nproc`
Number of NFS server threads.  Defaults to the recommended value of 8.


*Type:* signed integer

statdPort.description:
### option `services.nfs.server.statdPort`
Use a fixed port for {command}`rpc.statd`. This is
useful if the NFS server is behind a firewall.


*Type:* null or signed integer

settings.description:
### option `services.nfs.settings`
General configuration for NFS daemons and tools.
See nfs.conf(5) and related man pages for details.


*Type:* attribute set of section of an INI file (attrs of INI atom (null, bool, int, float or string))

statdPort.description:
### option `services.nfs.statdPort`
Alias of {option}`services.nfs.server.statdPort`.

*Type:* null or signed integer

backend-address-family.description:
### option `services.nghttpx.backend-address-family`
Specify address family of backend connections. If "auto" is
given, both IPv4 and IPv6 are considered. If "IPv4" is given,
only IPv4 address is considered. If "IPv6" is given, only IPv6
address is considered.

Please see https://nghttp2.org/documentation/nghttpx.1.html#cmdoption-nghttpx--backend-address-family


*Type:* one of "auto", "IPv4", "IPv6"

backends.description:
### option `services.nghttpx.backends`
A list of backend specifications.


*Type:* list of (submodule)

backlog.description:
### option `services.nghttpx.backlog`
Listen backlog size.

Please see https://nghttp2.org/documentation/nghttpx.1.html#cmdoption-nghttpx--backlog


*Type:* signed integer

enable.description:
### option `services.nghttpx.enable`
Whether to enable nghttpx.

*Type:* boolean

extraConfig.description:
### option `services.nghttpx.extraConfig`
Extra configuration options to be appended to the generated
configuration file.


*Type:* strings concatenated with "\n"

frontends.description:
### option `services.nghttpx.frontends`
A list of frontend listener specifications.


*Type:* list of (submodule)

rlimit-nofile.description:
### option `services.nghttpx.rlimit-nofile`
Set maximum number of open files (RLIMIT_NOFILE) to \<N\>. If 0
is given, nghttpx does not set the limit.

Please see https://nghttp2.org/documentation/nghttpx.1.html#cmdoption-nghttpx--rlimit-nofile


*Type:* signed integer

single-process.description:
### option `services.nghttpx.single-process`
Run this program in a single process mode for debugging
purpose. Without this option, nghttpx creates at least 2
processes: master and worker processes. If this option is
used, master and worker are unified into a single
process. nghttpx still spawns additional process if neverbleed
is used. In the single process mode, the signal handling
feature is disabled.

Please see https://nghttp2.org/documentation/nghttpx.1.html#cmdoption-nghttpx--single-process


*Type:* boolean

single-thread.description:
### option `services.nghttpx.single-thread`
Run everything in one thread inside the worker process. This
feature is provided for better debugging experience, or for
the platforms which lack thread support. If threading is
disabled, this option is always enabled.

Please see https://nghttp2.org/documentation/nghttpx.1.html#cmdoption-nghttpx--single-thread


*Type:* boolean

tls.description:
### option `services.nghttpx.tls`
TLS certificate and key paths. Note that this does not enable
TLS for a frontend listener, to do so, a frontend
specification must set `params.tls` to true.


*Type:* null or (submodule)

workers.description:
### option `services.nghttpx.workers`
Set the number of worker threads.

Please see https://nghttp2.org/documentation/nghttpx.1.html#cmdoption-nghttpx-n


*Type:* signed integer

additionalModules.description:
### option `services.nginx.additionalModules`
Additional [third-party nginx modules](https://www.nginx.com/resources/wiki/modules/)
to install. Packaged modules are available in `pkgs.nginxModules`.


*Type:* list of attribute set of anything

appendConfig.description:
### option `services.nginx.appendConfig`
Configuration lines appended to the generated Nginx
configuration file. Commonly used by different modules
providing http snippets. {option}`appendConfig`
can be specified more than once and its value will be
concatenated (contrary to {option}`config` which
can be set only once).


*Type:* strings concatenated with "\n"

appendHttpConfig.description:
### option `services.nginx.appendHttpConfig`
Configuration lines to be appended to the generated http block.
This is mutually exclusive with using config and httpConfig for
specifying the whole http block verbatim.


*Type:* strings concatenated with "\n"

clientMaxBodySize.description:
### option `services.nginx.clientMaxBodySize`
Set nginx global client_max_body_size.

*Type:* string

commonHttpConfig.description:
### option `services.nginx.commonHttpConfig`
With nginx you must provide common http context definitions before
they are used, e.g. log_format, resolver, etc. inside of server
or location contexts. Use this attribute to set these definitions
at the appropriate location.


*Type:* strings concatenated with "\n"

config.description:
### option `services.nginx.config`
Verbatim {file}`nginx.conf` configuration.
This is mutually exclusive to any other config option for
{file}`nginx.conf` except for
- [](#opt-services.nginx.appendConfig)
- [](#opt-services.nginx.httpConfig)
- [](#opt-services.nginx.logError)

If additional verbatim config in addition to other options is needed,
[](#opt-services.nginx.appendConfig) should be used instead.


*Type:* string

defaultHTTPListenPort.description:
### option `services.nginx.defaultHTTPListenPort`
If vhosts do not specify listen.port, use these ports for HTTP by default.


*Type:* 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

defaultListen.description:
### option `services.nginx.defaultListen`
If vhosts do not specify listen, use these addresses by default.
This option takes precedence over {option}`defaultListenAddresses` and
other listen-related defaults options.


*Type:* list of (submodule)

defaultListenAddresses.description:
### option `services.nginx.defaultListenAddresses`
If vhosts do not specify listenAddresses, use these addresses by default.
This is akin to writing `defaultListen = [ { addr = "0.0.0.0" } ]`.


*Type:* list of string

defaultMimeTypes.description:
### option `services.nginx.defaultMimeTypes`
Default MIME types for NGINX, as MIME types definitions from NGINX are very incomplete,
we use by default the ones bundled in the mailcap package, used by most of the other
Linux distributions.


*Type:* path

defaultSSLListenPort.description:
### option `services.nginx.defaultSSLListenPort`
If vhosts do not specify listen.port, use these ports for SSL by default.


*Type:* 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

enable.description:
### option `services.nginx.enable`
Whether to enable Nginx Web Server.

*Type:* boolean

enableQuicBPF.description:
### option `services.nginx.enableQuicBPF`
Enables routing of QUIC packets using eBPF. When enabled, this allows
to support QUIC connection migration. The directive is only supported
on Linux 5.7+.
Note that enabling this option will make nginx run with extended
capabilities that are usually limited to processes running as root
namely `CAP_SYS_ADMIN` and `CAP_NET_ADMIN`.


*Type:* boolean

enableReload.description:
### option `services.nginx.enableReload`
Reload nginx when configuration file changes (instead of restart).
The configuration file is exposed at {file}`/etc/nginx/nginx.conf`.
See also `systemd.services.*.restartIfChanged`.


*Type:* boolean

eventsConfig.description:
### option `services.nginx.eventsConfig`
Configuration lines to be set inside the events block.


*Type:* strings concatenated with "\n"

enable.description:
### option `services.nginx.gitweb.enable`
If true, enable gitweb in nginx.


*Type:* boolean

group.description:
### option `services.nginx.gitweb.group`
Group that the CGI process will belong to. (Set to `config.services.gitolite.group` if you are using gitolite.)


*Type:* string

location.description:
### option `services.nginx.gitweb.location`
Location to serve gitweb on.


*Type:* string

user.description:
### option `services.nginx.gitweb.user`
Existing user that the CGI process will belong to. (Default almost surely will do.)


*Type:* string

virtualHost.description:
### option `services.nginx.gitweb.virtualHost`
VirtualHost to serve gitweb on. Default is catch-all.


*Type:* string

group.description:
### option `services.nginx.group`
Group account under which nginx runs.

*Type:* string

httpConfig.description:
### option `services.nginx.httpConfig`
Configuration lines to be set inside the http block.
This is mutually exclusive with the structured configuration
via virtualHosts and the recommendedXyzSettings configuration
options. See appendHttpConfig for appending to the generated http block.


*Type:* strings concatenated with "\n"

logError.description:
### option `services.nginx.logError`
Configures logging.
The first parameter defines a file that will store the log. The
special value stderr selects the standard error file. Logging to
syslog can be configured by specifying the “syslog:” prefix.
The second parameter determines the level of logging, and can be
one of the following: debug, info, notice, warn, error, crit,
alert, or emerg. Log levels above are listed in the order of
increasing severity. Setting a certain log level will cause all
messages of the specified and more severe log levels to be logged.
If this parameter is omitted then error is used.


*Type:* string

mapHashBucketSize.description:
### option `services.nginx.mapHashBucketSize`
Sets the bucket size for the map variables hash tables. Default
value depends on the processor’s cache line size.


*Type:* null or one of 32, 64, 128

mapHashMaxSize.description:
### option `services.nginx.mapHashMaxSize`
Sets the maximum size of the map variables hash tables.


*Type:* null or (positive integer, meaning >0)

package.description:
### option `services.nginx.package`
Nginx package to use. This defaults to the stable version. Note
that the nginx team recommends to use the mainline version which
available in nixpkgs as `nginxMainline`.
Supported Nginx forks include `angie`, `openresty` and `tengine`.
For HTTP/3 support use `nginxQuic` or `angieQuic`.


*Type:* package

preStart.description:
### option `services.nginx.preStart`
Shell commands executed before the service's nginx is started.


*Type:* strings concatenated with "\n"

enable.description:
### option `services.nginx.proxyCache.enable`
Alias of {option}`services.nginx.proxyCachePath."".enable`.

*Type:* submodule

proxyCachePath.description:
### option `services.nginx.proxyCachePath`
Configure a proxy cache path entry.
See <https://nginx.org/en/docs/http/ngx_http_proxy_module.html#proxy_cache_path> for documentation.


*Type:* attribute set of (submodule)

proxyResolveWhileRunning.description:
### option `services.nginx.proxyResolveWhileRunning`
Resolves domains of proxyPass targets at runtime and not only at startup.
This can be used as a workaround if nginx fails to start because of not-yet-working DNS.

:::{.warn}
`services.nginx.resolver` must be set for this option to work.
:::


*Type:* boolean

proxyTimeout.description:
### option `services.nginx.proxyTimeout`
Change the proxy related timeouts in recommendedProxySettings.


*Type:* string

recommendedBrotliSettings.description:
### option `services.nginx.recommendedBrotliSettings`
Enable recommended brotli settings.
Learn more about compression in Brotli format [here](https://github.com/google/ngx_brotli/).

This adds `pkgs.nginxModules.brotli` to `services.nginx.additionalModules`.


*Type:* boolean

recommendedGzipSettings.description:
### option `services.nginx.recommendedGzipSettings`
Enable recommended gzip settings.
Learn more about compression in Gzip format [here](https://docs.nginx.com/nginx/admin-guide/web-server/compression/).


*Type:* boolean

recommendedOptimisation.description:
### option `services.nginx.recommendedOptimisation`
Enable recommended optimisation settings.


*Type:* boolean

recommendedProxySettings.description:
### option `services.nginx.recommendedProxySettings`
Whether to enable recommended proxy settings if a vhost does not specify the option manually.


*Type:* boolean

recommendedTlsSettings.description:
### option `services.nginx.recommendedTlsSettings`
Enable recommended TLS settings.


*Type:* boolean

recommendedZstdSettings.description:
### option `services.nginx.recommendedZstdSettings`
Enable recommended zstd settings.
Learn more about compression in Zstd format [here](https://github.com/tokers/zstd-nginx-module).

This adds `pkgs.nginxModules.zstd` to `services.nginx.additionalModules`.


*Type:* boolean

resolver.description:
### option `services.nginx.resolver`
Configures name servers used to resolve names of upstream servers into addresses


*Type:* submodule

serverNamesHashBucketSize.description:
### option `services.nginx.serverNamesHashBucketSize`
Sets the bucket size for the server names hash tables. Default
value depends on the processor’s cache line size.


*Type:* null or (positive integer, meaning >0)

serverNamesHashMaxSize.description:
### option `services.nginx.serverNamesHashMaxSize`
Sets the maximum size of the server names hash tables.


*Type:* null or (positive integer, meaning >0)

serverTokens.description:
### option `services.nginx.serverTokens`
Show nginx version in headers and error pages.

*Type:* boolean

sslCiphers.description:
### option `services.nginx.sslCiphers`
Ciphers to choose from when negotiating TLS handshakes.

*Type:* null or string

sslDhparam.description:
### option `services.nginx.sslDhparam`
Path to DH parameters file.

*Type:* null or path

sslProtocols.description:
### option `services.nginx.sslProtocols`
Allowed TLS protocol versions.

*Type:* string

configuration.description:
### option `services.nginx.sso.configuration`
nginx-sso configuration
([documentation](https://github.com/Luzifer/nginx-sso/wiki/Main-Configuration))
as a Nix attribute set.


*Type:* attribute set of unspecified value

enable.description:
### option `services.nginx.sso.enable`
Whether to enable nginx-sso service.

*Type:* boolean

package.description:
### option `services.nginx.sso.package`
The nginx-sso package to use.

*Type:* package

stateDir.description:
### option `services.nginx.stateDir`


*Type:* unspecified value

statusPage.description:
### option `services.nginx.statusPage`
Enable status page reachable from localhost on http://127.0.0.1/nginx_status.


*Type:* boolean

streamConfig.description:
### option `services.nginx.streamConfig`
Configuration lines to be set inside the stream block.


*Type:* strings concatenated with "\n"

enable.description:
### option `services.nginx.tailscaleAuth.enable`
Whether to enable tailscale.nginx-auth, to authenticate nginx users via tailscale.

*Type:* boolean

expectedTailnet.description:
### option `services.nginx.tailscaleAuth.expectedTailnet`
If you want to prevent node sharing from allowing users to access services
across tailnets, declare your expected tailnets domain here.


*Type:* null or string

group.description:
### option `services.nginx.tailscaleAuth.group`
Alias of {option}`services.tailscaleAuth.group`.

*Type:* string

package.description:
### option `services.nginx.tailscaleAuth.package`
Alias of {option}`services.tailscaleAuth.package`.

*Type:* package

user.description:
### option `services.nginx.tailscaleAuth.user`
Alias of {option}`services.tailscaleAuth.user`.

*Type:* string

virtualHosts.description:
### option `services.nginx.tailscaleAuth.virtualHosts`
A list of nginx virtual hosts to put behind tailscale.nginx-auth


*Type:* list of string

typesHashMaxSize.description:
### option `services.nginx.typesHashMaxSize`
Sets the maximum size of the types hash tables (`types_hash_max_size`).
It is recommended that the minimum size possible size is used.
If {option}`recommendedOptimisation` is disabled, nginx would otherwise
fail to start since the mailmap `mime.types` database has more entries
than the nginx default value 1024.


*Type:* positive integer, meaning >0

upstreams.description:
### option `services.nginx.upstreams`
Defines a group of servers to use as proxy target.


*Type:* attribute set of (submodule)

user.description:
### option `services.nginx.user`
User account under which nginx runs.

*Type:* string

validateConfigFile.description:
### option `services.nginx.validateConfigFile`
Whether to enable validating configuration with pkgs.writeNginxConfig.

*Type:* boolean

virtualHosts.description:
### option `services.nginx.virtualHosts`
Declarative vhost config

*Type:* attribute set of (submodule)

config.description:
### option `services.ngircd.config`
The ngircd configuration (see ngircd.conf(5)).

*Type:* strings concatenated with "\n"

enable.description:
### option `services.ngircd.enable`
Whether to enable the ngircd IRC server.

*Type:* boolean

package.description:
### option `services.ngircd.package`
The ngircd package to use.

*Type:* package

enable.description:
### option `services.nifi.enable`
Whether to enable Apache NiFi.

*Type:* boolean

enableHTTPS.description:
### option `services.nifi.enableHTTPS`
Enable HTTPS protocol. Don`t use in production.

*Type:* boolean

group.description:
### option `services.nifi.group`
Group account where Apache NiFi runs.

*Type:* string

initJavaHeapSize.description:
### option `services.nifi.initJavaHeapSize`
Set the initial heap size for the JVM in MB.

*Type:* null or signed integer

initPasswordFile.description:
### option `services.nifi.initPasswordFile`
nitial password for Apache NiFi. Password must be at least 12 characters.

*Type:* null or path

initUser.description:
### option `services.nifi.initUser`
Initial user account for Apache NiFi. Username must be at least 4 characters.

*Type:* null or string

listenHost.description:
### option `services.nifi.listenHost`
Bind to an ip for Apache NiFi web-ui.

*Type:* string

listenPort.description:
### option `services.nifi.listenPort`
Bind to a port for Apache NiFi web-ui.

*Type:* signed integer

maxJavaHeapSize.description:
### option `services.nifi.maxJavaHeapSize`
Set the initial heap size for the JVM in MB.

*Type:* null or signed integer

package.description:
### option `services.nifi.package`
Apache NiFi package to use.

*Type:* package

proxyHost.description:
### option `services.nifi.proxyHost`
Allow requests from a specific host.

*Type:* null or string

proxyPort.description:
### option `services.nifi.proxyPort`
Allow requests from a specific port.

*Type:* null or signed integer

user.description:
### option `services.nifi.user`
User account where Apache NiFi runs.

*Type:* string

listMinutes.description:
### option `services.nitter.cache.listMinutes`
How long to cache list info (not the tweets, so keep it high).

*Type:* signed integer

redisConnections.description:
### option `services.nitter.cache.redisConnections`
Redis connection pool size.

*Type:* signed integer

redisMaxConnections.description:
### option `services.nitter.cache.redisMaxConnections`
Maximum number of connections to Redis.

New connections are opened when none are available, but if the
pool size goes above this, they are closed when released, do not
worry about this unless you receive tons of requests per second.


*Type:* signed integer

redisPort.description:
### option `services.nitter.cache.redisPort`
Redis port.

*Type:* 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

rssMinutes.description:
### option `services.nitter.cache.rssMinutes`
How long to cache RSS queries.

*Type:* signed integer

config.description: ### module `services.nitter.config`

base64Media.description:
### option `services.nitter.config.base64Media`
Use base64 encoding for proxied media URLs.

*Type:* boolean

enableDebug.description:
### option `services.nitter.config.enableDebug`
Whether to enable request logs and debug endpoints.

*Type:* boolean

enableRSS.description:
### option `services.nitter.config.enableRSS`
Whether to enable RSS feeds.

*Type:* boolean

proxy.description:
### option `services.nitter.config.proxy`
URL to a HTTP/HTTPS proxy.

*Type:* string

tokenCount.description:
### option `services.nitter.config.tokenCount`
Minimum amount of usable tokens.

Tokens are used to authorize API requests, but they expire after
~1 hour, and have a limit of 187 requests. The limit gets reset
every 15 minutes, and the pool is filled up so there is always at
least tokenCount usable tokens. Only increase this if you receive
major bursts all the time.


*Type:* signed integer

enable.description:
### option `services.nitter.enable`
Whether to enable Nitter, an alternative Twitter front-end.

*Type:* boolean

guestAccounts.description:
### option `services.nitter.guestAccounts`
Path to the guest accounts file.

This file contains a list of guest accounts that can be used to
access the instance without logging in. The file is in JSONL format,
where each line is a JSON object with the following fields:

{"oauth_token":"some_token","oauth_token_secret":"some_secret_key"}

See https://github.com/zedeus/nitter/wiki/Guest-Account-Branch-Deployment
for more information on guest accounts and how to generate them.


*Type:* path

openFirewall.description:
### option `services.nitter.openFirewall`
Open ports in the firewall for Nitter web interface.

*Type:* boolean

package.description:
### option `services.nitter.package`
The nitter package to use.

*Type:* package

bidiSupport.description:
### option `services.nitter.preferences.bidiSupport`
Support bidirectional text (makes clicking on tweets harder).

*Type:* boolean

hideTweetStats.description:
### option `services.nitter.preferences.hideTweetStats`
Hide tweet stats (replies, retweets, likes).

*Type:* boolean

hlsPlayback.description:
### option `services.nitter.preferences.hlsPlayback`
Enable HLS video streaming (requires JavaScript).

*Type:* boolean

infiniteScroll.description:
### option `services.nitter.preferences.infiniteScroll`
Infinite scrolling (requires JavaScript, experimental!).

*Type:* boolean

mp4Playback.description:
### option `services.nitter.preferences.mp4Playback`
Enable MP4 video playback.

*Type:* boolean

muteVideos.description:
### option `services.nitter.preferences.muteVideos`
Mute videos by default.

*Type:* boolean

proxyVideos.description:
### option `services.nitter.preferences.proxyVideos`
Proxy video streaming through the server (might be slow).

*Type:* boolean

replaceReddit.description:
### option `services.nitter.preferences.replaceReddit`
Replace Reddit links with links to this instance (blank to disable).

*Type:* string

replaceTwitter.description:
### option `services.nitter.preferences.replaceTwitter`
Replace Twitter links with links to this instance (blank to disable).

*Type:* string

replaceYouTube.description:
### option `services.nitter.preferences.replaceYouTube`
Replace YouTube links with links to this instance (blank to disable).

*Type:* string

stickyProfile.description:
### option `services.nitter.preferences.stickyProfile`
Make profile sidebar stick to top.

*Type:* boolean

redisCreateLocally.description:
### option `services.nitter.redisCreateLocally`
Configure local Redis server for Nitter.

dnsmasq.description:
### option `services.nixops-dns.dnsmasq`
Enable dnsmasq forwarding to nixops-dns. This allows to use
nixops-dns for `services.nixops-dns.domain` resolution
while forwarding the rest of the queries to original resolvers.

Fake domain name to resolve to NixOps virtual machines.

For example "ops" will resolve "vm.ops".

of NixOps virtual machines via dnsmasq and fake domain name.

have the .nixops directory in its home.

define.description:

List of settings.js overrides to pass via -D to Node-RED.

*Type:* attribute set

enable.description:
### option `services.node-red.enable`
Whether to enable the Node-RED service.

*Type:* boolean

group.description:
### option `services.node-red.group`
Group under which Node-RED runs.If left as the default value this group
will automatically be created on system activation, otherwise the
sysadmin is responsible for ensuring the group exists.


*Type:* string

openFirewall.description:
### option `services.node-red.openFirewall`
Open ports in the firewall for the server.


*Type:* boolean

### option `services.node-red.package`
The node-red package to use.

port.description:
### option `services.node-red.port`
Listening port.

Whether to launch Node-RED in --safe mode.

User under which Node-RED runs.If left as the default value this user
will automatically be created on system activation, otherwise the
sysadmin is responsible for ensuring the user exists.


*Type:* string

userDir.description:
### option `services.node-red.userDir`
The directory to store all user data, such as flow and credential files and all library data. If left
as the default value this directory will automatically be created before the node-red service starts,
otherwise the sysadmin is responsible for ensuring the directory exists with appropriate ownership
and permissions.


*Type:* path

withNpmAndGcc.description:
### option `services.node-red.withNpmAndGcc`
Give Node-RED access to NPM and GCC at runtime, so 'Nodes' can be
downloaded and managed imperatively via the 'Palette Manager'.


*Type:* boolean

credentials.description:
### option `services.nomad.credentials`
Credentials envs used to configure nomad secrets.


*Type:* attribute set of string

dropPrivileges.description:
### option `services.nomad.dropPrivileges`
Whether the nomad agent should be run as a non-root nomad user.


*Type:* boolean

enable.description:
### option `services.nomad.enable`
Whether to enable Nomad, a distributed, highly available, datacenter-aware scheduler.

*Type:* boolean

enableDocker.description:
### option `services.nomad.enableDocker`
Enable Docker support. Needed for Nomad's docker driver.

Note that the docker group membership is effectively equivalent
to being root, see https://github.com/moby/moby/issues/9976.


*Type:* boolean

extraPackages.description:
### option `services.nomad.extraPackages`
Extra packages to add to {env}`PATH` for the Nomad agent process.


*Type:* list of package

extraSettingsPaths.description:
### option `services.nomad.extraSettingsPaths`
Additional settings paths used to configure nomad. These can be files or directories.


*Type:* list of path

extraSettingsPlugins.description:
### option `services.nomad.extraSettingsPlugins`
Additional plugins dir used to configure nomad.


*Type:* list of (package or path)

package.description:
### option `services.nomad.package`
The nomad package to use.

*Type:* package

settings.description:
### option `services.nomad.settings`
Configuration for Nomad. See the [documentation](https://www.nomadproject.io/docs/configuration)
for supported values.

Notes about `data_dir`:

If `data_dir` is set to a value other than the
default value of `"/var/lib/nomad"` it is the Nomad
cluster manager's responsibility to make sure that this directory
exists and has the appropriate permissions.

Additionally, if `dropPrivileges` is
`true` then `data_dir`
*cannot* be customized. Setting
`dropPrivileges` to `true` enables
the `DynamicUser` feature of systemd which directly
manages and operates on `StateDirectory`.


*Type:* JSON value

enable.description:
### option `services.novacomd.enable`
Whether to enable Novacom service for connecting to WebOS devices.

*Type:* boolean

config.description:
### option `services.nscd.config`
Configuration to use for Name Service Cache Daemon.
Only used in case glibc-nscd is used.


*Type:* strings concatenated with "\n"

enable.description:
### option `services.nscd.enable`
Whether to enable the Name Service Cache Daemon.
Disabling this is strongly discouraged, as this effectively disables NSS Lookups
from all non-glibc NSS modules, including the ones provided by systemd.


*Type:* boolean

enableNsncd.description:
### option `services.nscd.enableNsncd`
Whether to use nsncd instead of nscd from glibc.
This is a nscd-compatible daemon, that proxies lookups, without any caching.
Using nscd from glibc is discouraged.


*Type:* boolean

group.description:
### option `services.nscd.group`
User group under which nscd runs.


*Type:* string

package.description:
### option `services.nscd.package`
package containing the nscd binary to be used by the service.
Ignored when enableNsncd is set to true.


*Type:* package

user.description:
### option `services.nscd.user`
User account under which nscd runs.


*Type:* string

bind8Stats.description:
### option `services.nsd.bind8Stats`
Whether to enable BIND8 like statistics.

*Type:* boolean

dnssecInterval.description:
### option `services.nsd.dnssecInterval`
How often to check whether dnssec key rollover is required


*Type:* string

enable.description:
### option `services.nsd.enable`
Whether to enable NSD authoritative DNS server.

*Type:* boolean

extraConfig.description:
### option `services.nsd.extraConfig`
Extra nsd config.


*Type:* strings concatenated with "\n"

hideVersion.description:
### option `services.nsd.hideVersion`
Whether NSD should answer VERSION.BIND and VERSION.SERVER CHAOS class queries.


*Type:* boolean

identity.description:
### option `services.nsd.identity`
Identify the server (CH TXT ID.SERVER entry).


*Type:* string

interfaces.description:
### option `services.nsd.interfaces`
What addresses the server should listen to.


*Type:* list of string

ipFreebind.description:
### option `services.nsd.ipFreebind`
Whether to bind to nonlocal addresses and interfaces that are down.
Similar to ip-transparent.


*Type:* boolean

ipTransparent.description:
### option `services.nsd.ipTransparent`
Allow binding to non local addresses.


*Type:* boolean

ipv4.description:
### option `services.nsd.ipv4`
Whether to listen on IPv4 connections.


*Type:* boolean

ipv4EDNSSize.description:
### option `services.nsd.ipv4EDNSSize`
Preferred EDNS buffer size for IPv4.


*Type:* signed integer

ipv6.description:
### option `services.nsd.ipv6`
Whether to listen on IPv6 connections.


*Type:* boolean

ipv6EDNSSize.description:
### option `services.nsd.ipv6EDNSSize`
Preferred EDNS buffer size for IPv6.


*Type:* signed integer

keys.description:
### option `services.nsd.keys`
Define your TSIG keys here.


*Type:* attribute set of (submodule)

logTimeAscii.description:
### option `services.nsd.logTimeAscii`
Log time in ascii, if false then in unix epoch seconds.


*Type:* boolean

nsid.description:
### option `services.nsd.nsid`
NSID identity (hex string, or "ascii_somestring").


*Type:* null or string

port.description:
### option `services.nsd.port`
Port the service should bind do.


*Type:* 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

enable.description:
### option `services.nsd.ratelimit.enable`
Whether to enable ratelimit capabilities.

*Type:* boolean

ipv4PrefixLength.description:
### option `services.nsd.ratelimit.ipv4PrefixLength`
IPv4 prefix length. Addresses are grouped by netblock.


*Type:* null or signed integer

ipv6PrefixLength.description:
### option `services.nsd.ratelimit.ipv6PrefixLength`
IPv6 prefix length. Addresses are grouped by netblock.


*Type:* null or signed integer

ratelimit.description:
### option `services.nsd.ratelimit.ratelimit`
Max qps allowed from any query source.
0 means unlimited. With an verbosity of 2 blocked and
unblocked subnets will be logged.


*Type:* signed integer

size.description:
### option `services.nsd.ratelimit.size`
Size of the hashtable. More buckets use more memory but lower
the chance of hash hash collisions.


*Type:* signed integer

slip.description:
### option `services.nsd.ratelimit.slip`
Number of packets that get discarded before replying a SLIP response.
0 disables SLIP responses. 1 will make every response a SLIP response.


*Type:* null or signed integer

whitelistRatelimit.description:
### option `services.nsd.ratelimit.whitelistRatelimit`
Max qps allowed from whitelisted sources.
0 means unlimited. Set the rrl-whitelist option for specific
queries to apply this limit instead of the default to them.


*Type:* signed integer

controlCertFile.description:
### option `services.nsd.remoteControl.controlCertFile`
Path to the client certificate signed with the server certificate.
This file is used by nsd-control and generated by nsd-control-setup.


*Type:* path

controlKeyFile.description:
### option `services.nsd.remoteControl.controlKeyFile`
Path to the client private key, which is used by nsd-control
but not by the server. This file is generated by nsd-control-setup.


*Type:* path

enable.description:
### option `services.nsd.remoteControl.enable`
Whether to enable remote control via nsd-control.

*Type:* boolean

interfaces.description:
### option `services.nsd.remoteControl.interfaces`
Which interfaces NSD should bind to for remote control.


*Type:* list of string

port.description:
### option `services.nsd.remoteControl.port`
Port number for remote control operations (uses TLS over TCP).


*Type:* 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

serverCertFile.description:
### option `services.nsd.remoteControl.serverCertFile`
Path to the server self signed certificate, which is used by the server
but and by nsd-control. This file is generated by nsd-control-setup.


*Type:* path

serverKeyFile.description:
### option `services.nsd.remoteControl.serverKeyFile`
Path to the server private key, which is used by the server
but not by nsd-control. This file is generated by nsd-control-setup.


*Type:* path

reuseport.description:
### option `services.nsd.reuseport`
Whether to enable SO_REUSEPORT on all used sockets. This lets multiple
processes bind to the same port. This speeds up operation especially
if the server count is greater than one and makes fast restarts less
prone to fail


*Type:* boolean

rootServer.description:
### option `services.nsd.rootServer`
Whether this server will be a root server (a DNS root server, you
usually don't want that).


*Type:* boolean

roundRobin.description:
### option `services.nsd.roundRobin`
Whether to enable round robin rotation of records.

*Type:* boolean

serverCount.description:
### option `services.nsd.serverCount`
Number of NSD servers to fork. Put the number of CPUs to use here.


*Type:* signed integer

statistics.description:
### option `services.nsd.statistics`
Statistics are produced every number of seconds. Prints to log.
If null no statistics are logged.


*Type:* null or signed integer

tcpCount.description:
### option `services.nsd.tcpCount`
Maximum number of concurrent TCP connections per server.


*Type:* signed integer

tcpQueryCount.description:
### option `services.nsd.tcpQueryCount`
Maximum number of queries served on a single TCP connection.
0 means no maximum.


*Type:* signed integer

tcpTimeout.description:
### option `services.nsd.tcpTimeout`
TCP timeout in seconds.


*Type:* signed integer

version.description:
### option `services.nsd.version`
The version string replied for CH TXT version.server and version.bind
queries. Will use the compiled package version on null.
See hideVersion for enabling/disabling this responses.


*Type:* null or string

xfrdReloadTimeout.description:
### option `services.nsd.xfrdReloadTimeout`
Number of seconds between reloads triggered by xfrd.


*Type:* signed integer

zonefilesCheck.description:
### option `services.nsd.zonefilesCheck`
Whether to check mtime of all zone files on start and sighup.


*Type:* boolean

zonefilesWrite.description:
### option `services.nsd.zonefilesWrite`
Write changed secondary zones to their zonefile every N seconds.
If the zone (pattern) configuration has "" zonefile, it is not written.
Zones that have received zone transfer updates are written to their zonefile.
0 disables writing to zone files.


*Type:* signed integer

zones.description:
### option `services.nsd.zones`
Define your zones here. Zones can cascade other zones and therefore
inherit settings from parent zones. Look at the definition of
children to learn about inheritance and child zones.
The given example will define 3 zones (example.(com|org|net).). Both
example.com. and example.org. inherit their configuration from
serverGroup1.


*Type:* attribute set of (submodule)

enable.description:
### option `services.ntfy-sh.enable`
Whether to enable [ntfy-sh](https://ntfy.sh), a push notification service.

*Type:* boolean

group.description:
### option `services.ntfy-sh.group`
Primary group of ntfy-sh user.

*Type:* string

package.description:
### option `services.ntfy-sh.package`
The ntfy-sh package to use.

*Type:* package

settings.description:
### option `services.ntfy-sh.settings`
Configuration for ntfy.sh, supported values are [here](https://ntfy.sh/docs/config/#config-options).


*Type:* YAML value

user.description:
### option `services.ntfy-sh.user`
User the ntfy-sh server runs under.

*Type:* string

configText.description:
### option `services.ntopng.configText`
Overridable configuration file contents to use for ntopng. By
default, use the contents automatically generated by NixOS.


*Type:* strings concatenated with "\n"

enable.description:
### option `services.ntopng.enable`
Enable ntopng, a high-speed web-based traffic analysis and flow
collection tool.

With the default configuration, ntopng monitors all network
interfaces and displays its findings at http://localhost:${toString
config.services.ntopng.http-port}. Default username and password is admin/admin.

See the ntopng(8) manual page and http://www.ntop.org/products/ntop/
for more info.

Note that enabling ntopng will also enable redis (key-value
database server) for persistent data storage.


*Type:* boolean

extraConfig.description:
### option `services.ntopng.extraConfig`
Configuration lines that will be appended to the generated ntopng
configuration file. Note that this mechanism does not work when the
manual {option}`configText` option is used.


*Type:* strings concatenated with "\n"

httpPort.description:
### option `services.ntopng.httpPort`
Sets the HTTP port of the embedded web server.


*Type:* signed integer

interfaces.description:
### option `services.ntopng.interfaces`
List of interfaces to monitor. Use "any" to monitor all interfaces.


*Type:* list of string

address.description:
### option `services.ntopng.redis.address`
Redis address - may be a Unix socket or a network host and port.


*Type:* string

createInstance.description:
### option `services.ntopng.redis.createInstance`
Local Redis instance name. Set to `null` to disable
local Redis instance. Defaults to `""` for
`system.stateVersion` older than 22.05.


*Type:* null or string

enable.description:
### option `services.ntp.enable`
Whether to synchronise your machine's time using ntpd, as a peer in
the NTP network.

Disables `systemd.timesyncd` if enabled.


*Type:* boolean

extraConfig.description:
### option `services.ntp.extraConfig`
Additional text appended to {file}`ntp.conf`.


*Type:* strings concatenated with "\n"

extraFlags.description:
### option `services.ntp.extraFlags`
Extra flags passed to the ntpd command.

*Type:* list of string

restrictDefault.description:
### option `services.ntp.restrictDefault`
The restriction flags to be set by default.

The default flags prevent external hosts from using ntpd as a DDoS
reflector, setting system time, and querying OS/ntpd version. As
recommended in section 6.5.1.1.3, answer "No" of
https://support.ntp.org/Support/AccessRestrictions


*Type:* list of string

restrictSource.description:
### option `services.ntp.restrictSource`
The restriction flags to be set on source.

The default flags allow peers to be added by ntpd from configured
pool(s), but not by other means.


*Type:* list of string

servers.description:
### option `services.ntp.servers`
The set of NTP servers from which to synchronise.


*Type:* list of string

enable.description:
### option `services.ntpd-rs.enable`
Whether to enable Network Time Service (ntpd-rs).

*Type:* boolean

### option `services.ntpd-rs.metrics.enable`
Whether to enable ntpd-rs Prometheus Metrics Exporter.

*Type:* boolean

package.description:
### option `services.ntpd-rs.package`
The ntpd-rs package to use.

*Type:* package

settings.description:
### option `services.ntpd-rs.settings`
Settings to write to {file}`ntp.toml`

See <https://docs.ntpd-rs.pendulum-project.org/man/ntp.toml.5>
for more information about available options.


*Type:* TOML value

useNetworkingTimeServers.description:
### option `services.ntpd-rs.useNetworkingTimeServers`
Use source time servers from {var}`networking.timeServers` in config.


*Type:* boolean

enable.description:
### option `services.nullidentdmod.enable`
Whether to enable the nullidentdmod identd daemon.

*Type:* boolean

userid.description:
### option `services.nullidentdmod.userid`
User ID to return. Set to null to return a random string each time.

*Type:* null or string

config.description: ### module `services.nullmailer.config`

adminaddr.description:
### option `services.nullmailer.config.adminaddr`
If set, all recipients to users at either "localhost" (the literal string)
or the canonical host name (from the me control attribute) are remapped to this address.
This is provided to allow local daemons to be able to send email to
"somebody@localhost" and have it go somewhere sensible instead of being  bounced
by your relay host. To send to multiple addresses,
put them all on one line separated by a comma.


*Type:* null or string

allmailfrom.description:
### option `services.nullmailer.config.allmailfrom`
If set, content will override the envelope sender on all messages.


*Type:* null or string

defaultdomain.description:
### option `services.nullmailer.config.defaultdomain`
The content of this attribute is appended to any host name that
does not contain a period (except localhost), including defaulthost
and idhost. Defaults to the value of the me attribute, if it exists,
otherwise the literal name defauldomain.


*Type:* null or string

defaulthost.description:
### option `services.nullmailer.config.defaulthost`
The content of this attribute is appended to any address that
is missing a host name. Defaults to the value of the me control
attribute, if it exists, otherwise the literal name defaulthost.


*Type:* null or string

doublebounceto.description:
### option `services.nullmailer.config.doublebounceto`
If the original sender was empty (the original message was a
delivery status or disposition notification), the double bounce
is sent to the address in this attribute.


*Type:* null or string

helohost.description:
### option `services.nullmailer.config.helohost`
Sets  the  environment variable $HELOHOST which is used by the
SMTP protocol module to set the parameter given to the HELO command.
Defaults to the value of the me configuration attribute.


*Type:* null or string

idhost.description:
### option `services.nullmailer.config.idhost`
The content of this attribute is used when building the message-id
string for the message. Defaults to the canonicalized value of defaulthost.


*Type:* null or string

maxpause.description:
### option `services.nullmailer.config.maxpause`
The maximum time to pause between successive queue runs, in seconds.
Defaults to 24 hours (86400).


*Type:* null or string or signed integer

me.description:
### option `services.nullmailer.config.me`
The fully-qualifiled host name of the computer running nullmailer.
Defaults to the literal name me.


*Type:* null or string

pausetime.description:
### option `services.nullmailer.config.pausetime`
The minimum time to pause between successive queue runs when there
are messages in the queue, in seconds. Defaults to 1 minute (60).
Each time this timeout is reached, the timeout is doubled to a
maximum of maxpause. After new messages are injected, the timeout
is reset.  If this is set to 0, nullmailer-send will exit
immediately after going through the queue once (one-shot mode).


*Type:* null or string or signed integer

remotes.description:
### option `services.nullmailer.config.remotes`
A list of remote servers to which to send each message. Each line
contains a remote host name or address followed by an optional
protocol string, separated by white space.

See `man 8 nullmailer-send` for syntax and available
options.

WARNING: This is stored world-readable in the nix store. If you need
to specify any secret credentials here, consider using the
`remotesFile` option instead.


*Type:* null or string

sendtimeout.description:
### option `services.nullmailer.config.sendtimeout`
The  time to wait for a remote module listed above to complete sending
a message before killing it and trying again, in seconds.
Defaults to 1 hour (3600).  If this is set to 0, nullmailer-send
will wait forever for messages to complete sending.


*Type:* null or string or signed integer

enable.description:
### option `services.nullmailer.enable`
Whether to enable nullmailer daemon.

*Type:* boolean

group.description:
### option `services.nullmailer.group`
Group to use to run nullmailer-send.


*Type:* string

remotesFile.description:
### option `services.nullmailer.remotesFile`
Path to the `remotes` control file. This file contains a
list of remote servers to which to send each message.

See `man 8 nullmailer-send` for syntax and available
options.


*Type:* null or string

setSendmail.description:
### option `services.nullmailer.setSendmail`
Whether to set the system sendmail to nullmailer's.

*Type:* boolean

user.description:
### option `services.nullmailer.user`
User to use to run nullmailer-send.


*Type:* string

resource.description:

clientID.description:

clientSecret.description:

domain.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.cookie.domain`
Optional cookie domains to force cookies to (ie: `.yourcompany.com`).
The longest domain matching the request's host will be used (or the shortest
cookie domain if there is no match).

expire.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.cookie.expire`
Expire timeframe for cookie.


*Type:* string

httpOnly.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.cookie.httpOnly`
Set HttpOnly cookie flag.


*Type:* boolean

name.description:

The name of the cookie that the oauth_proxy creates.

refresh.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.cookie.refresh`
Refresh the cookie after this duration; 0 to disable.


*Type:* null or string

secret.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.cookie.secret`
The seed string for secure cookies.


*Type:* null or string

secure.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.cookie.secure`
Set secure (HTTPS) cookie flag.


*Type:* boolean

customTemplatesDir.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.customTemplatesDir`
Path to custom HTML templates.


*Type:* null or path

addresses.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.email.addresses`
Line-separated email addresses that are allowed to authenticate.


*Type:* null or strings concatenated with "\n"

domains.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.email.domains`
Authenticate emails with the specified domains. Use
`*` to authenticate any email.


*Type:* list of string

enable.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.enable`
Whether to enable oauth2-proxy.

*Type:* boolean

extraConfig.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.extraConfig`
Extra config to pass to oauth2-proxy.


*Type:* attribute set of anything

org.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.github.org`
Restrict logins to members of this organisation.


*Type:* null or string

team.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.github.team`
Restrict logins to members of this team.


*Type:* null or string

adminEmail.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.google.adminEmail`
The Google Admin to impersonate for API calls.

Only users with access to the Admin APIs can access the Admin SDK
Directory API, thus the service account needs to impersonate one of
those users to access the Admin SDK Directory API.

See <https://developers.google.com/admin-sdk/directory/v1/guides/delegation#delegate_domain-wide_authority_to_your_service_account>.


*Type:* string

groups.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.google.groups`
Restrict logins to members of these Google groups.


*Type:* list of string

serviceAccountJSON.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.google.serviceAccountJSON`
The path to the service account JSON credentials.


*Type:* path

displayForm.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.htpasswd.displayForm`
Display username / password login form if an htpasswd file is provided.


*Type:* boolean

file.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.htpasswd.file`
Additionally authenticate against a htpasswd file. Entries must be
created with `htpasswd -s` for SHA encryption.


*Type:* null or path

httpAddress.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.httpAddress`
HTTPS listening address.  This module does not expose the port by
default. If you want this URL to be accessible to other machines, please
add the port to `networking.firewall.allowedTCPPorts`.


*Type:* string

keyFile.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.keyFile`
oauth2-proxy allows passing sensitive configuration via environment variables.
Make a file that contains lines like
OAUTH2_PROXY_CLIENT_SECRET=asdfasdfasdf.apps.googleuserscontent.com
and specify the path here.


*Type:* null or path

loginURL.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.loginURL`
Authentication endpoint.

You only need to set this if you are using a self-hosted provider (e.g.
Github Enterprise). If you're using a publicly hosted provider
(e.g github.com), then the default works.


*Type:* null or string

domain.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.nginx.domain`
The domain under which the oauth2-proxy will be accesible and the path of cookies are set to.
This setting must be set to ensure back-redirects are working properly
if oauth2-proxy is configured with {option}`services.oauth2-proxy.cookie.domain`
or multiple {option}`services.oauth2-proxy.nginx.virtualHosts` that are not on the same domain.


*Type:* string

proxy.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.nginx.proxy`
The address of the reverse proxy endpoint for oauth2-proxy


*Type:* string

virtualHosts.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.nginx.virtualHosts`
Nginx virtual hosts to put behind the oauth2 proxy.
You can exclude specific locations by setting `auth_request off;` in the locations extraConfig setting.


*Type:* (attribute set of (submodule)) or (list of string) convertible to it

oidcIssuerUrl.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.oidcIssuerUrl`
The OAuth issuer URL.


*Type:* null or string

package.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.package`
The oauth2-proxy package to use.

*Type:* package

passAccessToken.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.passAccessToken`
Pass OAuth access_token to upstream via X-Forwarded-Access-Token header.


*Type:* boolean

passBasicAuth.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.passBasicAuth`
Pass HTTP Basic Auth, X-Forwarded-User and X-Forwarded-Email information to upstream.


*Type:* boolean

passHostHeader.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.passHostHeader`
Pass the request Host Header to upstream.


*Type:* boolean

profileURL.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.profileURL`
Profile access endpoint.


*Type:* null or string

proxyPrefix.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.proxyPrefix`
The url root path that this proxy should be nested under.


*Type:* string

redeemURL.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.redeemURL`
Token redemption endpoint.

You only need to set this if you are using a self-hosted provider (e.g.
Github Enterprise). If you're using a publicly hosted provider
(e.g github.com), then the default works.


*Type:* null or string

redirectURL.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.redirectURL`
The OAuth2 redirect URL.


*Type:* null or string

requestLogging.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.requestLogging`
Log requests to stdout.


*Type:* boolean

reverseProxy.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.reverseProxy`
In case when running behind a reverse proxy, controls whether headers
like `X-Real-Ip` are accepted. Usage behind a reverse
proxy will require this flag to be set to avoid logging the reverse
proxy IP address.


*Type:* boolean

scope.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.scope`
OAuth scope specification.


*Type:* null or string

setXauthrequest.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.setXauthrequest`
Set X-Auth-Request-User and X-Auth-Request-Email response headers (useful in Nginx auth_request mode). Setting this to 'null' means using the upstream default (false).


*Type:* null or boolean

signatureKey.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.signatureKey`
GAP-Signature request signature key.


*Type:* null or string

skipAuthRegexes.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.skipAuthRegexes`
Skip authentication for requests matching any of these regular
expressions.


*Type:* list of string

certificate.description:

Path to certificate file.


*Type:* path

enable.description:

Whether to serve over TLS.


*Type:* boolean

httpsAddress.description:

`addr:port` to listen on for HTTPS clients.

Remember to add `port` to
`allowedTCPPorts` if you want other machines to be
able to connect to it.


*Type:* string

key.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.tls.key`
Path to private key file.


*Type:* path

upstream.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.upstream`
The http url(s) of the upstream endpoint or `file://`
paths for static files. Routing is based on the path.


*Type:* (list of string) or string convertible to it

validateURL.description:
### option `services.oauth2-proxy.validateURL`
Access token validation endpoint.

You only need to set this if you are using a self-hosted provider (e.g.
Github Enterprise). If you're using a publicly hosted provider
(e.g github.com), then the default works.


*Type:* null or string

address.description:
### option `services.ocis.address`
Web interface address.

*Type:* string

configDir.description:
### option `services.ocis.configDir`
Path to directory containing oCIS config file.

Example config can be generated by `ocis init --config-path fileName --admin-password "adminPass"`.
Add `--insecure true` if SSL certificates are generated and managed externally (e.g. using oCIS behind reverse proxy).

Note: This directory must contain at least a `ocis.yaml`. Ensure
[user](#opt-services.ocis.user) has read/write access to it. In some
circumstances you may need to add additional oCIS configuration files (e.g.,
`proxy.yaml`) to this directory.


*Type:* null or path

enable.description:
### option `services.ocis.enable`
Whether to enable ownCloud Infinite Scale.

*Type:* boolean

environment.description:
### option `services.ocis.environment`
Extra config options.

See [the documentation](https://doc.owncloud.com/ocis/next/deployment/services/services.html) for available options.
See [notes for environment variables](https://doc.owncloud.com/ocis/next/deployment/services/env-var-note.html) for more information.

Note that all the attributes here will be copied to /nix/store/ and will be world readable. Options like *_PASSWORD or *_SECRET should be part of     [environmentFile](#opt-services.ocis.environmentFile) instead, and are only provided here for illustrative purpose.

Configuration here will override those from [environmentFile](#opt-services.ocis.environmentFile) and will have highest precedence, at the cost of security. Do NOT put security sensitive stuff here.


*Type:* attribute set of string

environmentFile.description:
### option `services.ocis.environmentFile`
An environment file as defined in {manpage}`systemd.exec(5)`.

Configuration provided in this file will override those from [configDir](#opt-services.ocis.configDir)/ocis.yaml.


*Type:* null or path

group.description:
### option `services.ocis.group`
The group to run oCIS under.
By default, a group named `ocis` will be created.


*Type:* string

package.description:
### option `services.ocis.package`
The ocis-bin package to use.

*Type:* package

port.description:
### option `services.ocis.port`
Web interface port.

*Type:* 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

stateDir.description:

ownCloud data directory.

*Type:* string

user.description:
### option `services.ocis.user`
The user to run oCIS as.
By default, a user named `ocis` will be created whose home
directory is [stateDir](#opt-services.ocis.stateDir).


*Type:* string

config.description:

Configuration content to start an OCServ server.

For a full configuration reference,please refer to the online documentation
(https://ocserv.gitlab.io/www/manual.html), the openconnect
recipes (https://github.com/openconnect/recipes) or `man ocserv`.

State directory of the daemon.

User for the daemon.

Whether to enable automatically initialize the DB.

Extra flags passed to odoo when run for the first time by autoInit

Domain to host Odoo with nginx

Whether to enable odoo, an open source ERP and CRM system.

enable.description:
### option `services.offlineimap.enable`
Whether to enable OfflineIMAP, a software to dispose your mailbox(es) as a local Maildir(s).

*Type:* boolean

install.description:
### option `services.offlineimap.install`
Whether to install a user service for Offlineimap. Once
the service is started, emails will be fetched automatically.

The service must be manually started for each user with
"systemctl --user start offlineimap" or globally through
{var}`services.offlineimap.enable`.


*Type:* boolean

onCalendar.description:
### option `services.offlineimap.onCalendar`
How often is offlineimap started. Default is '*:0/3' meaning every 3 minutes. See systemd.time(7) for more information about the format.

*Type:* string

package.description:
### option `services.offlineimap.package`
The offlineimap package to use.

*Type:* package

path.description:
### option `services.offlineimap.path`
List of derivations to put in Offlineimap's path.

*Type:* list of path

timeoutStartSec.description:
### option `services.offlineimap.timeoutStartSec`
How long waiting for offlineimap before killing it. Default is '120sec' meaning every 2 minutes. See systemd.time(7) for more information about the format.

*Type:* string

enable.description:
### option `services.ofono.enable`
Whether to enable Ofono.

*Type:* boolean

plugins.description:
### option `services.ofono.plugins`
The list of plugins to install.


*Type:* list of package

enable.description:
### option `services.oidentd.enable`
Whether to enable ‘oidentd’, an implementation of the Ident
protocol (RFC 1413).  It allows remote systems to identify the
name of the user associated with a TCP connection.


*Type:* boolean

domains.description:
### option `services.oink.domains`
List of attribute sets containing configuration for each domain.

Each attribute set must have two attributes, one named *domain*
and another named *subdomain*. The domain attribute must specify
the root domain that you want to configure, and the subdomain
attribute must specify its subdomain if any. If you want to
configure the root domain rather than a subdomain, leave the
subdomain attribute as an empty string.

Additionally, you can use attributes from *services.oink.settings*
to override settings per-domain.

Every domain listed here *must* have API access enabled in
Porkbun's control panel.


*Type:* list of attribute set of anything

enable.description:
### option `services.oink.enable`
Whether to enable Oink, a dynamic DNS client for Porkbun.

*Type:* boolean

package.description:
### option `services.oink.package`
The oink package to use.

*Type:* package

settings.description: ### module `services.oink.settings`

apiKey.description:
### option `services.oink.settings.apiKey`
API key to use when modifying DNS records.

*Type:* string

interval.description:
### option `services.oink.settings.interval`
Seconds to wait before sending another request.

*Type:* integer between 60 and 172800 (both inclusive)

secretApiKey.description:
### option `services.oink.settings.secretApiKey`
Secret API key to use when modifying DNS records.

*Type:* string

ttl.description:
### option `services.oink.settings.ttl`
The TTL ("Time to Live") value to set for your DNS records.

The TTL controls how long in seconds your records will be cached
for. A smaller value will allow the record to update quicker.


*Type:* integer between 600 and 172800 (both inclusive)

acceleration.description:
### option `services.ollama.acceleration`
What interface to use for hardware acceleration.

- `null`: default behavior
  - if `nixpkgs.config.rocmSupport` is enabled, uses `"rocm"`
  - if `nixpkgs.config.cudaSupport` is enabled, uses `"cuda"`
  - otherwise defaults to `false`
- `false`: disable GPU, only use CPU
- `"rocm"`: supported by most modern AMD GPUs
  - may require overriding gpu type with `services.ollama.rocmOverrideGfx`
    if rocm doesn't detect your AMD gpu
- `"cuda"`: supported by most modern NVIDIA GPUs


*Type:* null or one of false, "rocm", "cuda"

enable.description:
### option `services.ollama.enable`
Whether to enable ollama server for local large language models.

*Type:* boolean

environmentVariables.description:
### option `services.ollama.environmentVariables`
Set arbitrary environment variables for the ollama service.

Be aware that these are only seen by the ollama server (systemd service),
not normal invocations like `ollama run`.
Since `ollama run` is mostly a shell around the ollama server, this is usually sufficient.


*Type:* attribute set of string

group.description:
### option `services.ollama.group`
Group under which to run ollama. Only used when `services.ollama.user` is set.

The group will automatically be created, if this option is set to a non-null value.


*Type:* null or string

home.description:
### option `services.ollama.home`
The home directory that the ollama service is started in.


*Type:* string

host.description:
### option `services.ollama.host`
The host address which the ollama server HTTP interface listens to.


*Type:* string

listenAddress.description:
### option `services.ollama.listenAddress`


*Type:* unspecified value

loadModels.description:
### option `services.ollama.loadModels`
Download these models using `ollama pull` as soon as `ollama.service` has started.

This creates a systemd unit `ollama-model-loader.service`.

Search for models of your choice from: https://ollama.com/library


*Type:* list of string

models.description:
### option `services.ollama.models`
The directory that the ollama service will read models from and download new models to.


*Type:* string

openFirewall.description:
### option `services.ollama.openFirewall`
Whether to open the firewall for ollama.

This adds `services.ollama.port` to `networking.firewall.allowedTCPPorts`.


*Type:* boolean

package.description:
### option `services.ollama.package`
The ollama package to use.

*Type:* package

port.description:
### option `services.ollama.port`
Which port the ollama server listens to.


*Type:* 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

rocmOverrideGfx.description:
### option `services.ollama.rocmOverrideGfx`
Override what rocm will detect your gpu model as.
For example, if you have an RX 5700 XT, try setting this to `"10.1.0"` (gfx 1010).

This sets the value of `HSA_OVERRIDE_GFX_VERSION`. See [ollama's docs](
https://github.com/ollama/ollama/blob/main/docs/gpu.md#amd-radeon
) for details.


*Type:* null or string

user.description:
### option `services.ollama.user`
User account under which to run ollama. Defaults to [`DynamicUser`](https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/latest/systemd.exec.html#DynamicUser=)
when set to `null`.

The user will automatically be created, if this option is set to a non-null value.


*Type:* null or string

Whether to enable Ombi, a web application that automatically gives your shared Plex or

Optionally see <https://docs.ombi.app/info/reverse-proxy>

examplePort.description:

jwtSecretFile.description:

Path to a file that contains the secret to sign web requests using JSON Web Tokens.
If left at the default value null signing is disabled.

The onlyoffice-documentserver package to use.

port.description:

Port the OnlyOffice document server should listen on.

The Postgresql hostname or socket path OnlyOffice should connect to.

postgresName.description:

The name of database OnlyOffice should use.

*Type:* string

Path to a file that contains the password OnlyOffice should use to connect to Postgresql.
Unused when using socket authentication.


*Type:* null or string

The username OnlyOffice should use to connect to Postgresql.

The Rabbitmq in amqp URI style OnlyOffice should connect to.
