dbPath.description:
### option `services.surrealdb.dbPath`
The path that surrealdb will write data to. Use null for in-memory.
Can be one of "memory", "rocksdb://:path", "surrealkv://:path", "tikv://:addr", "fdb://:addr".


*Type:* string

enable.description:
### option `services.surrealdb.enable`
Whether to enable SurrealDB, a scalable, distributed, collaborative, document-graph database, for the realtime web.

*Type:* boolean

extraFlags.description:
### option `services.surrealdb.extraFlags`
Specify a list of additional command line flags.


*Type:* list of string

host.description:
### option `services.surrealdb.host`
The host that surrealdb will connect to.


*Type:* string

package.description:
### option `services.surrealdb.package`
The surrealdb package to use.

*Type:* package

port.description:
### option `services.surrealdb.port`
The port that surrealdb will connect to.


*Type:* 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

dataDir.description:
### option `services.suwayomi-server.dataDir`
The path to the data directory in which Suwayomi-Server will download scans.


*Type:* path

enable.description:
### option `services.suwayomi-server.enable`
Whether to enable Suwayomi, a free and open source manga reader server that runs extensions built for Tachiyomi.

*Type:* boolean

group.description:
### option `services.suwayomi-server.group`
Group under which Suwayomi-Server runs.


*Type:* string

openFirewall.description:
### option `services.suwayomi-server.openFirewall`
Whether to open the firewall for the port in {option}`services.suwayomi-server.settings.server.port`.


*Type:* boolean

package.description:
### option `services.suwayomi-server.package`
The suwayomi-server package to use.

*Type:* package

settings.description:
### option `services.suwayomi-server.settings`
Configuration to write to {file}`server.conf`.
See <https://github.com/Suwayomi/Suwayomi-Server/wiki/Configuring-Suwayomi-Server> for more information.


*Type:* HOCON value

user.description:
### option `services.suwayomi-server.user`
User account under which Suwayomi-Server runs.


*Type:* string

enable.description:
### option `services.svnserve.enable`
Whether to enable svnserve to serve Subversion repositories through the SVN protocol.

*Type:* boolean

svnBaseDir.description:
### option `services.svnserve.svnBaseDir`
Base directory from which Subversion repositories are accessed.

*Type:* string

enable.description:
### option `services.swapspace.enable`
Whether to enable Swapspace, a dynamic swap space manager.

*Type:* boolean

extraArgs.description:
### option `services.swapspace.extraArgs`
Any extra arguments to pass to swapspace

*Type:* list of string

package.description:
### option `services.swapspace.package`
The swapspace package to use.

*Type:* package

settings.description:
### option `services.swapspace.settings`
Config file for swapspace.
See the options here: <https://github.com/Tookmund/Swapspace/blob/master/swapspace.conf>


*Type:* submodule

enable.description:
### option `services.switcherooControl.enable`
Whether to enable switcheroo-control, a D-Bus service to check the availability of dual-GPU.

*Type:* boolean

package.description:
### option `services.switcherooControl.package`
The switcheroo-control package to use.

*Type:* package

createLocally.description:
### option `services.sympa.database.createLocally`
Whether to create a local database automatically.

*Type:* boolean

host.description:
### option `services.sympa.database.host`
Database host address.

For MySQL, use `localhost` to connect using Unix domain socket.

For PostgreSQL, use path to directory (e.g. {file}`/run/postgresql`)
to connect using Unix domain socket located in this directory.

Use `null` to fall back on Sympa default, or when using
{option}`services.sympa.database.createLocally`.


*Type:* null or string

name.description:
### option `services.sympa.database.name`
Database name. When using SQLite this must be an absolute
path to the database file.


*Type:* string

passwordFile.description:
### option `services.sympa.database.passwordFile`
A file containing the password for {option}`services.sympa.database.name`.


*Type:* null or path

port.description:
### option `services.sympa.database.port`
Database port. Use `null` for default port.

*Type:* null or 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

type.description:
### option `services.sympa.database.type`
Database engine to use.

*Type:* one of "SQLite", "PostgreSQL", "MySQL"

user.description:
### option `services.sympa.database.user`
Database user. The system user name is used as a default.

*Type:* null or string

domains.description:
### option `services.sympa.domains`
Email domains handled by this instance. There have
to be MX records for keys of this attribute set.


*Type:* attribute set of (submodule)

enable.description:
### option `services.sympa.enable`
Whether to enable Sympa mailing list manager.

*Type:* boolean

lang.description:
### option `services.sympa.lang`
Default Sympa language.
See <https://github.com/sympa-community/sympa/tree/sympa-6.2/po/sympa>
for available options.


*Type:* string

listMasters.description:
### option `services.sympa.listMasters`
The list of the email addresses of the listmasters
(users authorized to perform global server commands).


*Type:* list of string

mainDomain.description:
### option `services.sympa.mainDomain`
Main domain to be used in {file}`sympa.conf`.
If `null`, one of the {option}`services.sympa.domains` is chosen for you.


*Type:* null or string

type.description:
### option `services.sympa.mta.type`
Mail transfer agent (MTA) integration. Use `none` if you want to configure it yourself.

The `postfix` integration sets up local Postfix instance that will pass incoming
messages from configured domains to Sympa. You still need to configure at least outgoing message
handling using e.g. {option}`services.postfix.relayHost`.


*Type:* one of "postfix", "none"

settings.description:
### option `services.sympa.settings`
The {file}`sympa.conf` configuration file as key value set.
See <https://sympa-community.github.io/gpldoc/man/sympa.conf.5.html>
for list of configuration parameters.


*Type:* attribute set of (string or signed integer or boolean)

settingsFile.description:
### option `services.sympa.settingsFile`
Set of files to be linked in {file}`/var/lib/sympa`.

*Type:* attribute set of (submodule)

enable.description:
### option `services.sympa.web.enable`
Whether to enable Sympa web interface.

*Type:* boolean

fcgiProcs.description:
### option `services.sympa.web.fcgiProcs`
Number of FastCGI processes to fork.

*Type:* positive integer, meaning >0

https.description:
### option `services.sympa.web.https`
Whether to use HTTPS. When nginx integration is enabled, this option forces SSL and enables ACME.
Please note that Sympa web interface always uses https links even when this option is disabled.


*Type:* boolean

server.description:
### option `services.sympa.web.server`
The webserver used for the Sympa web interface. Set it to `none` if you want to configure it yourself.
Further nginx configuration can be done by adapting
{option}`services.nginx.virtualHosts.«name»`.


*Type:* one of "nginx", "none"

commands.description:
### option `services.syncoid.commands`
Syncoid commands to run.

*Type:* attribute set of (submodule)

commonArgs.description:
### option `services.syncoid.commonArgs`
Arguments to add to every syncoid command, unless disabled for that
command. See
<https://github.com/jimsalterjrs/sanoid/#syncoid-command-line-options>
for available options.


*Type:* list of string

enable.description:
### option `services.syncoid.enable`
Whether to enable Syncoid ZFS synchronization service.

*Type:* boolean

group.description:
### option `services.syncoid.group`
The group for the service.

*Type:* string

interval.description:
### option `services.syncoid.interval`
Run syncoid at this interval. The default is to run hourly.

The format is described in
{manpage}`systemd.time(7)`.


*Type:* string

localSourceAllow.description:
### option `services.syncoid.localSourceAllow`
Permissions granted for the {option}`services.syncoid.user` user
for local source datasets. See
<https://openzfs.github.io/openzfs-docs/man/8/zfs-allow.8.html>
for available permissions.


*Type:* list of string

localTargetAllow.description:
### option `services.syncoid.localTargetAllow`
Permissions granted for the {option}`services.syncoid.user` user
for local target datasets. See
<https://openzfs.github.io/openzfs-docs/man/8/zfs-allow.8.html>
for available permissions.
Make sure to include the `change-key` permission if you send raw encrypted datasets,
the `compression` permission if you send raw compressed datasets, and so on.
For remote target datasets you'll have to set your remote user permissions by yourself.


*Type:* list of string

package.description:
### option `services.syncoid.package`
The sanoid package to use.

*Type:* package

service.description:
### option `services.syncoid.service`
Systemd configuration common to all syncoid services.


*Type:* attribute set

sshKey.description:
### option `services.syncoid.sshKey`
SSH private key file to use to login to the remote system. Can be
overridden in individual commands.


*Type:* null or (string or path convertible to it)

user.description:
### option `services.syncoid.user`
The user for the service. ZFS privilege delegation will be
automatically configured for any local pools used by syncoid if this
option is set to a user other than root. The user will be given the
"hold" and "send" privileges on any pool that has datasets being sent
and the "create", "mount", "receive", and "rollback" privileges on
any pool that has datasets being received.


*Type:* string

certDir.description:
### option `services.syncplay.certDir`
TLS certificates directory to use for encryption. See
<https://github.com/Syncplay/syncplay/wiki/TLS-support>.


*Type:* null or path

chat.description:
### option `services.syncplay.chat`
Chat with users in the same room.


*Type:* boolean

enable.description:
### option `services.syncplay.enable`
If enabled, start the Syncplay server.


*Type:* boolean

extraArgs.description:
### option `services.syncplay.extraArgs`
Additional arguments to be passed to the service.


*Type:* list of string

group.description:
### option `services.syncplay.group`


*Type:* unspecified value

interfaceIpv4.description:
### option `services.syncplay.interfaceIpv4`
The IP address to bind to for IPv4. Leaving it empty defaults to using all.


*Type:* string

interfaceIpv6.description:
### option `services.syncplay.interfaceIpv6`
The IP address to bind to for IPv6. Leaving it empty defaults to using all.


*Type:* string

ipv4Only.description:
### option `services.syncplay.ipv4Only`
Listen only on IPv4 when strting the server.


*Type:* boolean

ipv6Only.description:
### option `services.syncplay.ipv6Only`
Listen only on IPv6 when strting the server.


*Type:* boolean

maxChatMessageLength.description:
### option `services.syncplay.maxChatMessageLength`
Maximum number of characters in a chat message.


*Type:* unsigned integer, meaning >=0

maxUsernameLength.description:
### option `services.syncplay.maxUsernameLength`
Maximum number of characters in a username.


*Type:* unsigned integer, meaning >=0

motd.description:
### option `services.syncplay.motd`
Text to display when users join. The motd will be readable in the nix store
and the processlist.  If this is not intended use `motdFile` instead.
Will be overriden by {option}`services.syncplay.motdFile`.


*Type:* null or string

motdFile.description:
### option `services.syncplay.motdFile`
Path to text to display when users join.
Will override {option}`services.syncplay.motd`.


*Type:* null or string

package.description:
### option `services.syncplay.package`
Package to use for syncplay.


*Type:* package

passwordFile.description:
### option `services.syncplay.passwordFile`
Path to the file that contains the server password. If
`null`, the server doesn't require a password.


*Type:* null or path

permanentRooms.description:
### option `services.syncplay.permanentRooms`
List of rooms that will be listed even if the room is empty.
Will be overriden by {option}`services.syncplay.permanentRoomsFile`.


*Type:* list of string

permanentRoomsFile.description:
### option `services.syncplay.permanentRoomsFile`
File with list of rooms that will be listed even if the room is empty,
newline delimited.
Will override {option}`services.syncplay.permanentRooms`.


*Type:* null or string

port.description:
### option `services.syncplay.port`
TCP port to bind to.


*Type:* 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

ready.description:
### option `services.syncplay.ready`
Check readiness of users.


*Type:* boolean

roomsDBFile.description:
### option `services.syncplay.roomsDBFile`
Path to SQLite database file to store room states.
Relative to the working directory provided by systemd.


*Type:* null or string

salt.description:
### option `services.syncplay.salt`
Salt to allow room operator passwords generated by this server
instance to still work when the server is restarted.  The salt will be
readable in the nix store and the processlist.  If this is not
intended use `saltFile` instead.  Mutually exclusive with
{option}`services.syncplay.saltFile`.


*Type:* null or string

saltFile.description:
### option `services.syncplay.saltFile`
Path to the file that contains the server salt.  This allows room
operator passwords generated by this server instance to still work
when the server is restarted.  `null`, the server doesn't load the
salt from a file.  Mutually exclusive with
{option}`services.syncplay.salt`.


*Type:* null or path

statsDBFile.description:
### option `services.syncplay.statsDBFile`
Path to SQLite database file to store stats.
Relative to the working directory provided by systemd.


*Type:* null or string

useACMEHost.description:
### option `services.syncplay.useACMEHost`
If set, use NixOS-generated ACME certificate with the specified name for TLS.

Note that it requires {option}`security.acme` to be setup, e.g., credentials provided if using DNS-01 validation.


*Type:* null or string

user.description:
### option `services.syncplay.user`


*Type:* unspecified value

all_proxy.description:
### option `services.syncthing.all_proxy`
Overwrites the all_proxy environment variable for the Syncthing process to
the given value. This is normally used to let Syncthing connect
through a SOCKS5 proxy server.
See <https://docs.syncthing.net/users/proxying.html>.


*Type:* null or string

cert.description:
### option `services.syncthing.cert`
Path to the `cert.pem` file, which will be copied into Syncthing's
[configDir](#opt-services.syncthing.configDir).


*Type:* null or string

configDir.description:
### option `services.syncthing.configDir`
The path where the settings and keys will exist.


*Type:* path

dataDir.description:
### option `services.syncthing.dataDir`
The path where synchronised directories will exist.


*Type:* path

databaseDir.description:
### option `services.syncthing.databaseDir`
The directory containing the database and logs.


*Type:* path

cert.description:
### option `services.syncthing.declarative.cert`
Alias of {option}`services.syncthing.cert`.

*Type:* null or string

extraOptions.description:
### option `services.syncthing.declarative.extraOptions`
Alias of {option}`services.syncthing.extraOptions`.

*Type:* JSON value

key.description:
### option `services.syncthing.declarative.key`
Alias of {option}`services.syncthing.key`.

*Type:* null or string

enable.description:
### option `services.syncthing.enable`
Whether to enable Syncthing, a self-hosted open-source alternative to Dropbox and Bittorrent Sync.

*Type:* boolean

extraFlags.description:
### option `services.syncthing.extraFlags`
Extra flags passed to the syncthing command in the service definition.


*Type:* list of string

extraOptions.description:
### option `services.syncthing.extraOptions`
Alias of {option}`services.syncthing.settings`.

*Type:* JSON value

group.description:
### option `services.syncthing.group`
The group to run Syncthing under.
By default, a group named `syncthing` will be created.


*Type:* string

guiAddress.description:
### option `services.syncthing.guiAddress`
The address to serve the web interface at.


*Type:* string

key.description:
### option `services.syncthing.key`
Path to the `key.pem` file, which will be copied into Syncthing's
[configDir](#opt-services.syncthing.configDir).


*Type:* null or string

openDefaultPorts.description:
### option `services.syncthing.openDefaultPorts`
Whether to open the default ports in the firewall: TCP/UDP 22000 for transfers
and UDP 21027 for discovery.

If multiple users are running Syncthing on this machine, you will need
to manually open a set of ports for each instance and leave this disabled.
Alternatively, if you are running only a single instance on this machine
using the default ports, enable this.


*Type:* boolean

options.description:
### option `services.syncthing.options`
Alias of {option}`services.syncthing.settings.options`.

*Type:* submodule

overrideDevices.description:
### option `services.syncthing.overrideDevices`
Whether to delete the devices which are not configured via the
[devices](#opt-services.syncthing.settings.devices) option.
If set to `false`, devices added via the web
interface will persist and will have to be deleted manually.


*Type:* boolean

overrideFolders.description:
### option `services.syncthing.overrideFolders`
Whether to delete the folders which are not configured via the
[folders](#opt-services.syncthing.settings.folders) option.
If set to `false`, folders added via the web
interface will persist and will have to be deleted manually.


*Type:* boolean

package.description:
### option `services.syncthing.package`
The syncthing package to use.

*Type:* package

enable.description:
### option `services.syncthing.relay.enable`
Whether to enable Syncthing relay service.

*Type:* boolean

extraOptions.description:
### option `services.syncthing.relay.extraOptions`
Extra command line arguments to pass to strelaysrv.


*Type:* list of string

globalRateBps.description:
### option `services.syncthing.relay.globalRateBps`
Global bandwidth rate limit in bytes per second.


*Type:* null or (positive integer, meaning >0)

listenAddress.description:
### option `services.syncthing.relay.listenAddress`
Address to listen on for relay traffic.


*Type:* string

perSessionRateBps.description:
### option `services.syncthing.relay.perSessionRateBps`
Per session bandwidth rate limit in bytes per second.


*Type:* null or (positive integer, meaning >0)

pools.description:
### option `services.syncthing.relay.pools`
Relay pools to join. If null, uses the default global pool.


*Type:* null or (list of string)

port.description:
### option `services.syncthing.relay.port`
Port to listen on for relay traffic. This port should be added to
`networking.firewall.allowedTCPPorts`.


*Type:* 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

providedBy.description:
### option `services.syncthing.relay.providedBy`
Human-readable description of the provider of the relay (you).


*Type:* string

statusListenAddress.description:
### option `services.syncthing.relay.statusListenAddress`
Address to listen on for serving the relay status API.


*Type:* string

statusPort.description:
### option `services.syncthing.relay.statusPort`
Port to listen on for serving the relay status API. This port should be
added to `networking.firewall.allowedTCPPorts`.


*Type:* 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

systemService.description:
### option `services.syncthing.systemService`
Whether to auto-launch Syncthing as a system service.


*Type:* boolean

user.description:
### option `services.syncthing.user`
The user to run Syncthing as.
By default, a user named `syncthing` will be created whose home
directory is [dataDir](#opt-services.syncthing.dataDir).


*Type:* string

autoStart.description:
### option `services.synergy.client.autoStart`
Whether the Synergy client should be started automatically.

*Type:* boolean

enable.description:
### option `services.synergy.client.enable`
Whether to enable the Synergy client (receive keyboard and mouse events from a Synergy server).

*Type:* boolean

screenName.description:
### option `services.synergy.client.screenName`
Use the given name instead of the hostname to identify
ourselves to the server.


*Type:* string

serverAddress.description:
### option `services.synergy.client.serverAddress`
The server address is of the form: [hostname][:port].  The
hostname must be the address or hostname of the server.  The
port overrides the default port, 24800.


*Type:* string

address.description:
### option `services.synergy.server.address`
Address on which to listen for clients.

*Type:* string

autoStart.description:
### option `services.synergy.server.autoStart`
Whether the Synergy server should be started automatically.

*Type:* boolean

configFile.description:
### option `services.synergy.server.configFile`
The Synergy server configuration file.

*Type:* path

enable.description:
### option `services.synergy.server.enable`
Whether to enable the Synergy server (send keyboard and mouse events).

*Type:* boolean

screenName.description:
### option `services.synergy.server.screenName`
Use the given name instead of the hostname to identify
this screen in the configuration.


*Type:* string

cert.description:
### option `services.synergy.server.tls.cert`
The TLS certificate to use for encryption.

*Type:* null or string

enable.description:
### option `services.synergy.server.tls.enable`
Whether TLS encryption should be used.

Using this requires a TLS certificate that can be
generated by starting the Synergy GUI once and entering
a valid product key.


*Type:* boolean

configHeader.description:
### option `services.syslog-ng.configHeader`
The very first lines of the configuration file. Should usually contain
the syslog-ng version header.


*Type:* strings concatenated with "\n"

enable.description:
### option `services.syslog-ng.enable`
Whether to enable the syslog-ng daemon.


*Type:* boolean

extraConfig.description:
### option `services.syslog-ng.extraConfig`
Configuration added to the end of `syslog-ng.conf`.


*Type:* strings concatenated with "\n"

extraModulePaths.description:
### option `services.syslog-ng.extraModulePaths`
A list of paths that should be included in syslog-ng's
`--module-path` option. They should usually
end in `/lib/syslog-ng`


*Type:* list of string

package.description:
### option `services.syslog-ng.package`
The syslogng package to use.

*Type:* package

defaultConfig.description:
### option `services.syslogd.defaultConfig`
The default {file}`syslog.conf` file configures a
fairly standard setup of log files, which can be extended by
means of {var}`extraConfig`.


*Type:* strings concatenated with "\n"

enable.description:
### option `services.syslogd.enable`
Whether to enable syslogd.  Note that systemd also logs
syslog messages, so you normally don't need to run syslogd.


*Type:* boolean

enableNetworkInput.description:
### option `services.syslogd.enableNetworkInput`
Accept logging through UDP. Option -r of syslogd(8).


*Type:* boolean

extraConfig.description:
### option `services.syslogd.extraConfig`
Additional text appended to {file}`syslog.conf`,
i.e. the contents of {var}`defaultConfig`.


*Type:* strings concatenated with "\n"

extraParams.description:
### option `services.syslogd.extraParams`
Additional parameters passed to {command}`syslogd`.


*Type:* list of string

tty.description:
### option `services.syslogd.tty`
The tty device on which syslogd will print important log
messages. Leave this option blank to disable tty logging.


*Type:* string

enable.description:
### option `services.sysprof.enable`
Whether to enable sysprof profiling daemon.

*Type:* boolean

collect-args.description:
### option `services.sysstat.collect-args`
Arguments to pass sa1 when collecting statistics


*Type:* string

collect-frequency.description:
### option `services.sysstat.collect-frequency`
OnCalendar specification for sysstat-collect


*Type:* string

enable.description:
### option `services.sysstat.enable`
Whether to enable sar system activity collection.

*Type:* boolean

### option `services.system-config-printer.enable`
Whether to enable system-config-printer, a service for CUPS administration used by printing interfaces.

*Type:* boolean

assignments.description:
### option `services.system76-scheduler.assignments`
Process profile assignments.

*Type:* attribute set of (submodule)

enable.description:
### option `services.system76-scheduler.enable`
Whether to enable system76-scheduler.

*Type:* boolean

exceptions.description:
### option `services.system76-scheduler.exceptions`
Processes that are left alone.

*Type:* list of string

package.description:
### option `services.system76-scheduler.package`
Which System76-Scheduler package to use.

*Type:* package

settings.description: ### module `services.system76-scheduler.settings`

enable.description:
### option `services.system76-scheduler.settings.cfsProfiles.enable`
Tweak CFS latency parameters when going on/off battery

*Type:* boolean

### option `services.system76-scheduler.settings.processScheduler.enable`
Tweak scheduling of individual processes in real time.

*Type:* boolean

class.description:
### option `services.system76-scheduler.settings.processScheduler.foregroundBoost.background.class`
CPU scheduler class.

*Type:* null or one of "idle", "batch", "other", "rr", "fifo"

ioClass.description:
### option `services.system76-scheduler.settings.processScheduler.foregroundBoost.background.ioClass`
IO scheduler class.

*Type:* null or one of "idle", "best-effort", "realtime"

ioPrio.description:
### option `services.system76-scheduler.settings.processScheduler.foregroundBoost.background.ioPrio`
IO scheduler priority.

*Type:* null or integer between 0 and 7 (both inclusive)

matchers.description:
### option `services.system76-scheduler.settings.processScheduler.foregroundBoost.background.matchers`
Process matchers.

*Type:* null or (list of string)

nice.description:
### option `services.system76-scheduler.settings.processScheduler.foregroundBoost.background.nice`
Niceness.

*Type:* null or integer between -20 and 19 (both inclusive)

prio.description:
### option `services.system76-scheduler.settings.processScheduler.foregroundBoost.background.prio`
CPU scheduler priority.

*Type:* null or integer between 1 and 99 (both inclusive)

enable.description:
### option `services.system76-scheduler.settings.processScheduler.foregroundBoost.enable`
Boost foreground process priorities.

(And de-boost background ones).  Note that this option needs cooperation
from the desktop environment to work.  On Gnome the client side is
implemented by the "System76 Scheduler" shell extension.


*Type:* boolean

class.description:
### option `services.system76-scheduler.settings.processScheduler.foregroundBoost.foreground.class`
CPU scheduler class.

acceleration.description:
### option `services.tabby.acceleration`
Specifies the device to use for hardware acceleration.

-   `cpu`: no acceleration just use the CPU
-  `rocm`: supported by modern AMD GPUs
-  `cuda`: supported by modern NVIDIA GPUs
- `metal`: supported on darwin aarch64 machines

Tabby will try and determine what type of acceleration that is
already enabled in your configuration when `acceleration = null`.

- nixpkgs.config.cudaSupport
- nixpkgs.config.rocmSupport
- if stdenv.hostPlatform.isDarwin && stdenv.hostPlatform.isAarch64

IFF multiple acceleration methods are found to be enabled or if you
haven't set either `cudaSupport or rocmSupport` you will have to
specify the device type manually here otherwise it will default to
the first from the list above or to cpu.


*Type:* null or one of "cpu", "rocm", "cuda", "metal"

indexInterval.description:
### option `services.tabby.indexInterval`
Run tabby scheduler to generate the index database at this interval.
Updates by default every 5 hours. This value applies to
`OnUnitInactiveSec`

The format is described in
{manpage}`systemd.time(7)`.

To disable running `tabby scheduler --now` updates, set to `"never"`


*Type:* string

model.description:
### option `services.tabby.model`
Specify the model that tabby will use to generate completions.

This model will be downloaded automatically if it is not already present.

If you want to utilize an existing model that you've already
downloaded you'll need to move it into tabby's state directory which
lives in `/var/lib/tabby`. Because the tabby.service is configured to
use a DyanmicUser the service will need to have been started at least
once before you can move the locally existing model into
`/var/lib/tabby`. You can set the model to 'none' and tabby will
startup and fail to download a model, but will have created the
`/var/lib/tabby` directory. You can then copy over the model manually
into `/var/lib/tabby`, update the model option to the name you just
downloaded and copied over then `nixos-rebuild switch` to start using
it.

$ tabby download --model TabbyML/DeepseekCoder-6.7B
$ find ~/.tabby/ | tail -n1
/home/ghthor/.tabby/models/TabbyML/DeepseekCoder-6.7B/ggml/q8_0.v2.gguf
$ sudo rsync -r ~/.tabby/models/ /var/lib/tabby/models/
$ sudo chown -R tabby:tabby /var/lib/tabby/models/

See for Model Options:
> https://github.com/TabbyML/registry-tabby


*Type:* string

archives.description:
### option `services.tarsnap.archives`
Tarsnap archive configurations. Each attribute names an archive
to be created at a given time interval, according to the options
associated with it. When uploading to the tarsnap server,
archive names are suffixed by a 1 second resolution timestamp,
with the format `%Y%m%d%H%M%S`.

For each member of the set is created a timer which triggers the
instanced `tarsnap-archive-name` service unit. You may use
{command}`systemctl start tarsnap-archive-name` to
manually trigger creation of `archive-name` at
any time.


*Type:* attribute set of (submodule)

enable.description:
### option `services.tarsnap.enable`
Whether to enable periodic tarsnap backups.

*Type:* boolean

keyfile.description:
### option `services.tarsnap.keyfile`
The keyfile which associates this machine with your tarsnap
account.
Create the keyfile with {command}`tarsnap-keygen`.

Note that each individual archive (specified below) may also have its
own individual keyfile specified. Tarsnap does not allow multiple
concurrent backups with the same cache directory and key (starting a
new backup will cause another one to fail). If you have multiple
archives specified, you should either spread out your backups to be
far apart, or specify a separate key for each archive. By default
every archive defaults to using
`"/root/tarsnap.key"`.

It's recommended for backups that you generate a key for every archive
using `tarsnap-keygen(1)`, and then generate a
write-only tarsnap key using `tarsnap-keymgmt(1)`,
and keep your master key(s) for a particular machine off-site.

The keyfile name should be given as a string and not a path, to
avoid the key being copied into the Nix store.


*Type:* string

config.description:
### option `services.taskserver.config`
Configuration options to pass to Taskserver.

The options here are the same as described in
{manpage}`taskdrc(5)` from the `taskwarrior2` package, but with one difference:

The `server` option is
`server.listen` here, because the
`server` option would collide with other options
like `server.cert` and we would run in a type error
(attribute set versus string).

Nix types like integers or booleans are automatically converted to
the right values Taskserver would expect.


*Type:* attribute set

enable.description:

Whether to run the Teamspeak3 voice communication server daemon.

fileTransferIP.description:

IP on which the server instance will listen for incoming file transfer connections. Defaults to any IP.

fileTransferPort.description:

TCP port opened for file transfers.

logPath.description:

Directory to store log files in.

openFirewall.description:

Open ports in the firewall for the TeamSpeak3 server.

openFirewallServerQuery.description:

Open ports in the firewall for the TeamSpeak3 serverquery (administration) system. Requires openFirewall.

*Type:* boolean

queryHttpPort.description:
### option `services.teamspeak3.queryHttpPort`
TCP port opened for ServerQuery connections using the HTTP protocol.


*Type:* 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

queryIP.description:
### option `services.teamspeak3.queryIP`
IP on which the server instance will listen for incoming ServerQuery connections. Defaults to any IP.


*Type:* null or string

queryPort.description:
### option `services.teamspeak3.queryPort`
TCP port opened for ServerQuery connections using the raw telnet protocol.


*Type:* 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

querySshPort.description:
### option `services.teamspeak3.querySshPort`
TCP port opened for ServerQuery connections using the SSH protocol.


*Type:* 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

voiceIP.description:
### option `services.teamspeak3.voiceIP`
IP on which the server instance will listen for incoming voice connections. Defaults to any IP.


*Type:* null or string

enable.description:
### option `services.teamviewer.enable`
Whether to enable TeamViewer daemon & system package.

*Type:* boolean

package.description:
### option `services.teamviewer.package`
The teamviewer package to use.

*Type:* package

enable.description:
### option `services.technitium-dns-server.enable`
Whether to enable Technitium DNS Server.

*Type:* boolean

firewallTCPPorts.description:
### option `services.technitium-dns-server.firewallTCPPorts`
List of TCP ports to open in firewall.
You might want to open ports 443 and 853 if you intend to use DNS over HTTPS or DNS over TLS.


*Type:* list of signed integer

firewallUDPPorts.description:
### option `services.technitium-dns-server.firewallUDPPorts`
List of UDP ports to open in firewall.


*Type:* list of signed integer

openFirewall.description:
### option `services.technitium-dns-server.openFirewall`
Whether to open ports in the firewall.
Standard ports are 53 (UDP and TCP, for DNS), 5380 and 53443 (TCP, HTTP and HTTPS for web interface).
Specify different or additional ports in options firewallUDPPorts and firewallTCPPorts if necessary.


*Type:* boolean

package.description:
### option `services.technitium-dns-server.package`
The technitium-dns-server package to use.

*Type:* package

enable.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.enable`
Whether to enable Teeworlds Server.

*Type:* boolean

environmentFile.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.environmentFile`
Environment file as defined in {manpage}`systemd.exec(5)`.

Secrets may be passed to the service without adding them to the world-readable
Nix store, by specifying placeholder variables as the option value in Nix and
setting these variables accordingly in the environment file.

```
  # snippet of teeworlds-related config
  services.teeworlds.password = "$TEEWORLDS_PASSWORD";
```

```
  # content of the environment file
  TEEWORLDS_PASSWORD=verysecretpassword
```

Note that this file needs to be available on the host on which
`teeworlds` is running.


*Type:* null or path

extraOptions.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.extraOptions`
Extra configuration lines for the {file}`teeworlds.cfg`. See [Teeworlds Documentation](https://www.teeworlds.com/?page=docs&wiki=server_settings).


*Type:* list of string

enablePowerups.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.game.enablePowerups`
Whether to allow powerups such as the ninja.


*Type:* boolean

enableReadyMode.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.game.enableReadyMode`
Whether to enable "ready mode"; where players can pause/unpause the game
and start the game in warmup, using their ready state.


*Type:* boolean

enableTeamDamage.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.game.enableTeamDamage`
Whether to enable team damage; whether to allow team mates to inflict damage on one another.


*Type:* boolean

enableVoteKick.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.game.enableVoteKick`
Whether to enable voting to kick players.


*Type:* boolean

gameType.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.game.gameType`
The game type to use on the server.

The default gametypes are `dm`, `tdm`, `ctf`, `lms`, and `lts`.


*Type:* string

map.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.game.map`
The map to use on the server.


*Type:* string

playerSlots.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.game.playerSlots`
The amount of slots to reserve for players (as opposed to spectators).


*Type:* unsigned integer, meaning >=0

restrictSpectators.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.game.restrictSpectators`
Whether to restrict access to information such as health, ammo and armour in spectator mode.


*Type:* boolean

scoreLimit.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.game.scoreLimit`
The score limit needed to win a round.


*Type:* unsigned integer, meaning >=0

swapTeams.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.game.swapTeams`
Whether to swap teams each round.


*Type:* boolean

timeLimit.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.game.timeLimit`
Time limit of the game. In cases of equal points, there will be sudden death.
Setting this to 0 disables a time limit.


*Type:* unsigned integer, meaning >=0

tournamentMode.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.game.tournamentMode`
Whether to enable tournament mode. In tournament mode, players join as spectators.
If this is set to `restrictSpectators`, tournament mode is enabled but spectator chat is restricted.


*Type:* one of "disable", "enable", "restrictSpectators"

voteKickBanTime.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.game.voteKickBanTime`
The amount of minutes that a player is banned for if they get kicked by a vote.


*Type:* unsigned integer, meaning >=0

voteKickMinimumPlayers.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.game.voteKickMinimumPlayers`
The minimum amount of players required to start a kick vote.


*Type:* unsigned integer, meaning >=0

motd.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.motd`
The server's message of the day text.


*Type:* null or string

name.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.name`
Name of the server.


*Type:* string

openPorts.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.openPorts`
Whether to open firewall ports for Teeworlds.

*Type:* boolean

package.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.package`
The teeworlds-server package to use.

*Type:* package

password.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.password`
Password to connect to the server.


*Type:* null or string

port.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.port`
Port the server will listen on.


*Type:* 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

rconPassword.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.rconPassword`
Password to access the remote console. If not set, a randomly generated one is displayed in the server log.


*Type:* null or string

register.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.register`
Whether the server registers as a public server in the global server list. This is disabled by default for privacy reasons.


*Type:* boolean

bindAddr.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.server.bindAddr`
The address the server will bind to.


*Type:* null or string

enableHighBandwidth.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.server.enableHighBandwidth`
Whether to enable high bandwidth mode on LAN servers. This will double the amount of bandwidth required for running the server.


*Type:* boolean

enableSpamProtection.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.server.enableSpamProtection`
Whether to enable chat spam protection.


*Type:* boolean

hostName.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.server.hostName`
Hostname for the server.


*Type:* null or string

inactivePenalty.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.server.inactivePenalty`
Specify what to do when a client goes inactive (see [](#opt-services.teeworlds.server.inactiveTime)).

- `spectator`: send the client into spectator mode

- `spectator/kick`: send the client into a free spectator slot, otherwise kick the client

- `kick`: kick the client


*Type:* one of "spectator", "spectator/kick", "kick"

inactiveTime.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.server.inactiveTime`
The amount of minutes a client has to idle before it is considered inactive.


*Type:* unsigned integer, meaning >=0

kickInactiveSpectators.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.server.kickInactiveSpectators`
Whether to kick inactive spectators.


*Type:* boolean

maxClients.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.server.maxClients`
The maximum amount of clients that can be connected to the server at the same time.


*Type:* unsigned integer, meaning >=0

maxClientsPerIP.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.server.maxClientsPerIP`
The maximum amount of clients with the same IP address that can be connected to the server at the same time.


*Type:* unsigned integer, meaning >=0

skillLevel.description:
### option `services.teeworlds.server.skillLevel`
The skill level shown in the server browser.


*Type:* one of "casual", "normal", "competitive"

enable.description:
### option `services.telegraf.enable`
Whether to enable telegraf server.

*Type:* boolean

environmentFiles.description:
### option `services.telegraf.environmentFiles`
File to load as environment file. Environment variables from this file
will be interpolated into the config file using envsubst with this
syntax: `$ENVIRONMENT` or `${VARIABLE}`.
This is useful to avoid putting secrets into the nix store.


*Type:* list of path

extraConfig.description:
### option `services.telegraf.extraConfig`
Extra configuration options for telegraf

*Type:* TOML value

package.description:
### option `services.telegraf.package`
The telegraf package to use.

*Type:* package

enable.description:
### option `services.telepathy.enable`
Whether to enable Telepathy service, a communications framework
that enables real-time communication via pluggable protocol backends.


*Type:* boolean

addr.description:
### option `services.teleport.diag.addr`
Metrics and diagnostics address.

*Type:* string

enable.description:
### option `services.teleport.diag.enable`
Whether to enable endpoints for monitoring purposes.

See <https://goteleport.com/docs/setup/admin/troubleshooting/#troubleshooting/>
.

*Type:* boolean

port.description:
### option `services.teleport.diag.port`
Metrics and diagnostics port.

*Type:* 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

enable.description:
### option `services.teleport.enable`
Whether to enable the Teleport service.

*Type:* boolean

### option `services.teleport.insecure.enable`
Whether to enable starting teleport in insecure mode.

This is dangerous!
Sensitive information will be logged to console and certificates will not be verified.
Proceed with caution!

Teleport starts with disabled certificate validation on Proxy Service, validation still occurs on Auth Service
.

*Type:* boolean

package.description:
### option `services.teleport.package`
The teleport package to use.

*Type:* package

settings.description:
### option `services.teleport.settings`
Contents of the `teleport.yaml` config file.
The `--config` arguments will only be passed if this set is not empty.

See <https://goteleport.com/docs/setup/reference/config/>.


*Type:* YAML value

configFile.description:
### option `services.tempo.configFile`
Specify a path to a configuration file that Tempo should use.


*Type:* null or path

enable.description:
### option `services.tempo.enable`
Whether to enable Grafana Tempo.

*Type:* boolean

extraFlags.description:
### option `services.tempo.extraFlags`
Additional flags to pass to the `ExecStart=` in `tempo.service`.


*Type:* list of string

settings.description:
### option `services.tempo.settings`
Specify the configuration for Tempo in Nix.

See https://grafana.com/docs/tempo/latest/configuration/ for available options.


*Type:* YAML value

autoCreatedWorldSize.description:
### option `services.terraria.autoCreatedWorldSize`
Specifies the size of the auto-created world if `worldPath` does not
point to an existing world.


*Type:* one of "small", "medium", "large"

banListPath.description:
### option `services.terraria.banListPath`
The path to the ban list.


*Type:* null or path

dataDir.description:
### option `services.terraria.dataDir`
Path to variable state data directory for terraria.

*Type:* string

enable.description:
### option `services.terraria.enable`
If enabled, starts a Terraria server. The server can be connected to via `tmux -S ${config.services.terraria.dataDir}/terraria.sock attach`
for administration by users who are a part of the `terraria` group (use `C-b d` shortcut to detach again).


*Type:* boolean

maxPlayers.description:
### option `services.terraria.maxPlayers`
Sets the max number of players (between 1 and 255).


*Type:* 8 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 255 (both inclusive)

messageOfTheDay.description:
### option `services.terraria.messageOfTheDay`
Set the server message of the day text.


*Type:* null or string

noUPnP.description:
### option `services.terraria.noUPnP`
Disables automatic Universal Plug and Play.

*Type:* boolean

openFirewall.description:
### option `services.terraria.openFirewall`
Whether to open ports in the firewall

*Type:* boolean

password.description:
### option `services.terraria.password`
Sets the server password. Leave `null` for no password.


*Type:* null or string

port.description:
### option `services.terraria.port`
Specifies the port to listen on.


*Type:* 16 bit unsigned integer; between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive)

secure.description:
### option `services.terraria.secure`
Adds additional cheat protection to the server.

*Type:* boolean

worldPath.description:
### option `services.terraria.worldPath`
The path to the world file (`.wld`) which should be loaded.
If no world exists at this path, one will be created with the size
specified by `autoCreatedWorldSize`.


*Type:* null or path

enable.description:
### option `services.tetrd.enable`
Whether to enable tetrd.

*Type:* boolean

### option `services.tftpd.enable`
Whether to enable tftpd, a Trivial File Transfer Protocol server.
The server will be run as an xinetd service.


*Type:* boolean

path.description:
### option `services.tftpd.path`
Where the tftp server files are stored.


*Type:* path

arguments.description:
### option `services.thanos.compact.arguments`
Arguments to the `thanos compact` command.

Defaults to a list of arguments formed by converting the structured
options of {option}`services.thanos.compact` to a list of arguments.

Overriding this option will cause none of the structured options to have
any effect. So only set this if you know what you're doing!


*Type:* list of string

concurrency.description:
### option `services.thanos.compact.compact.concurrency`
Number of goroutines to use when compacting groups.

Defaults to `1` in Thanos
when set to `null`.


*Type:* null or signed integer

consistency-delay.description:
### option `services.thanos.compact.consistency-delay`
Minimum age of fresh (non-compacted) blocks before they are being
processed. Malformed blocks older than the maximum of consistency-delay
and 30m0s will be removed.

Defaults to `30m` in Thanos
when set to `null`.


*Type:* null or string

disable.description:
### option `services.thanos.compact.downsampling.disable`
Disables downsampling.

This is not recommended as querying long time ranges without
non-downsampled data is not efficient and useful e.g it is not possible
to render all samples for a human eye anyway


*Type:* boolean

enable.description:
### option `services.thanos.compact.enable`
Whether to enable the Thanos compactor which continuously compacts blocks in an object store bucket.

*Type:* boolean

http-address.description:
### option `services.thanos.compact.http-address`
Listen `host:port` for HTTP endpoints.

Defaults to `0.0.0.0:10902` in Thanos
when set to `null`.


*Type:* null or string

format.description:
### option `services.thanos.compact.log.format`
Log format to use.


*Type:* null or string

level.description:
### option `services.thanos.compact.log.level`
Log filtering level.

Defaults to `info` in Thanos
when set to `null`.


*Type:* null or one of "debug", "info", "warn", "error", "fatal"

config.description:
### option `services.thanos.compact.objstore.config`
Object store configuration.

When not `null` the attribute set gets converted to
a YAML file and stored in the Nix store. The option
{option}`objstore.config-file` will default to its path.

If {option}`objstore.config-file` is set this option has no effect.

See format details: <https://thanos.io/tip/thanos/storage.md/#configuring-access-to-object-storage>


*Type:* null or (attribute set)

config-file.description:
### option `services.thanos.compact.objstore.config-file`
Path to YAML file that contains object store configuration.

See format details: <https://thanos.io/tip/thanos/storage.md/#configuring-access-to-object-storage>


*Type:* null or string

resolution-1h.description:
### option `services.thanos.compact.retention.resolution-1h`
How long to retain samples of resolution 2 (1 hour) in bucket.

`0d` - disables this retention

Defaults to `0d` in Thanos
when set to `null`.


*Type:* null or string

resolution-5m.description:
### option `services.thanos.compact.retention.resolution-5m`
How long to retain samples of resolution 1 (5 minutes) in bucket.

`0d` - disables this retention

Defaults to `0d` in Thanos
when set to `null`.


*Type:* null or string

resolution-raw.description:
### option `services.thanos.compact.retention.resolution-raw`
How long to retain raw samples in bucket.

`0d` - disables this retention

Defaults to `0d` in Thanos
when set to `null`.


*Type:* null or string

startAt.description:
### option `services.thanos.compact.startAt`
When this option is set to a `systemd.time`
specification the Thanos compactor will run at the specified period.

When this option is `null` the Thanos compactor service
will run continuously. So it will not exit after all compactions have
been processed but wait for new work.


*Type:* null or string

stateDir.description:
### option `services.thanos.compact.stateDir`
Data directory relative to `/var/lib`
in which to cache blocks and process compactions.


*Type:* string

config.description:
### option `services.thanos.compact.tracing.config`
Tracing configuration.

When not `null` the attribute set gets converted to
a YAML file and stored in the Nix store. The option
{option}`tracing.config-file` will default to its path.

If {option}`tracing.config-file` is set this option has no effect.

See format details: <https://thanos.io/tip/thanos/tracing.md/#configuration>


*Type:* null or (attribute set)

config-file.description:
### option `services.thanos.compact.tracing.config-file`
Path to YAML file that contains tracing configuration.

See format details: <https://thanos.io/tip/thanos/tracing.md/#configuration>


*Type:* null or string

arguments.description:
### option `services.thanos.downsample.arguments`
Arguments to the `thanos downsample` command.

Defaults to a list of arguments formed by converting the structured
options of {option}`services.thanos.downsample` to a list of arguments.

Overriding this option will cause none of the structured options to have
any effect. So only set this if you know what you're doing!


*Type:* list of string

enable.description:
### option `services.thanos.downsample.enable`
Whether to enable the Thanos downsampler which continuously downsamples blocks in an object store bucket.

*Type:* boolean

format.description:
### option `services.thanos.downsample.log.format`
Log format to use.


*Type:* null or string

level.description:
### option `services.thanos.downsample.log.level`
Log filtering level.

Defaults to `info` in Thanos
when set to `null`.


*Type:* null or one of "debug", "info", "warn", "error", "fatal"

config.description:
### option `services.thanos.downsample.objstore.config`
Object store configuration.

When not `null` the attribute set gets converted to
a YAML file and stored in the Nix store. The option
{option}`objstore.config-file` will default to its path.

If {option}`objstore.config-file` is set this option has no effect.

See format details: <https://thanos.io/tip/thanos/storage.md/#configuring-access-to-object-storage>


*Type:* null or (attribute set)

config-file.description:
### option `services.thanos.downsample.objstore.config-file`
Path to YAML file that contains object store configuration.

See format details: <https://thanos.io/tip/thanos/storage.md/#configuring-access-to-object-storage>


*Type:* null or string

stateDir.description:
### option `services.thanos.downsample.stateDir`
Data directory relative to `/var/lib`
in which to cache blocks and process downsamplings.


*Type:* string

config.description:
### option `services.thanos.downsample.tracing.config`
Tracing configuration.

When not `null` the attribute set gets converted to
a YAML file and stored in the Nix store. The option
{option}`tracing.config-file` will default to its path.

If {option}`tracing.config-file` is set this option has no effect.

See format details: <https://thanos.io/tip/thanos/tracing.md/#configuration>


*Type:* null or (attribute set)

config-file.description:
### option `services.thanos.downsample.tracing.config-file`
Path to YAML file that contains tracing configuration.

See format details: <https://thanos.io/tip/thanos/tracing.md/#configuration>


*Type:* null or string

package.description:
### option `services.thanos.package`
The thanos package to use.

*Type:* package

arguments.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.arguments`
Arguments to the `thanos query` command.

Defaults to a list of arguments formed by converting the structured
options of {option}`services.thanos.query` to a list of arguments.

Overriding this option will cause none of the structured options to have
any effect. So only set this if you know what you're doing!


*Type:* list of string

enable.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.enable`
Whether to enable the Thanos query node exposing PromQL enabled Query API with data retrieved from multiple store nodes.

*Type:* boolean

endpoints.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.endpoints`
Addresses of statically configured Thanos API servers (repeatable).

The scheme may be prefixed with 'dns+' or 'dnssrv+' to detect
Thanos API servers through respective DNS lookups.


*Type:* list of string

grpc-address.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.grpc-address`
Listen `ip:port` address for gRPC endpoints (StoreAPI).

Make sure this address is routable from other components.

Defaults to `0.0.0.0:10901` in Thanos
when set to `null`.


*Type:* null or string

grpc-client-server-name.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.grpc-client-server-name`
Server name to verify the hostname on the returned gRPC certificates.
See <https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4366#section-3.1>


*Type:* null or string

grpc-client-tls-ca.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.grpc-client-tls-ca`
TLS CA Certificates to use to verify gRPC servers


*Type:* null or string

grpc-client-tls-cert.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.grpc-client-tls-cert`
TLS Certificates to use to identify this client to the server


*Type:* null or string

grpc-client-tls-key.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.grpc-client-tls-key`
TLS Key for the client's certificate


*Type:* null or string

grpc-client-tls-secure.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.grpc-client-tls-secure`
Use TLS when talking to the gRPC server


*Type:* boolean

grpc-compression.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.grpc-compression`
Compression algorithm to use for gRPC requests to other clients.


*Type:* null or string

grpc-server-tls-cert.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.grpc-server-tls-cert`
TLS Certificate for gRPC server, leave blank to disable TLS


*Type:* null or string

grpc-server-tls-client-ca.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.grpc-server-tls-client-ca`
TLS CA to verify clients against.

If no client CA is specified, there is no client verification on server side.
(tls.NoClientCert)


*Type:* null or string

grpc-server-tls-key.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.grpc-server-tls-key`
TLS Key for the gRPC server, leave blank to disable TLS


*Type:* null or string

http-address.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.http-address`
Listen `host:port` for HTTP endpoints.

Defaults to `0.0.0.0:10902` in Thanos
when set to `null`.


*Type:* null or string

format.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.log.format`
Log format to use.


*Type:* null or string

level.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.log.level`
Log filtering level.

Defaults to `info` in Thanos
when set to `null`.


*Type:* null or one of "debug", "info", "warn", "error", "fatal"

auto-downsampling.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.query.auto-downsampling`
Enable automatic adjustment (step / 5) to what source of data should
be used in store gateways if no
`max_source_resolution` param is specified.


*Type:* boolean

default-evaluation-interval.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.query.default-evaluation-interval`
Set default evaluation interval for sub queries.

Defaults to `1m` in Thanos
when set to `null`.


*Type:* null or string

max-concurrent.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.query.max-concurrent`
Maximum number of queries processed concurrently by query node.

Defaults to `20` in Thanos
when set to `null`.


*Type:* null or signed integer

partial-response.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.query.partial-response`
Enable partial response for queries if no
`partial_response` param is specified.


*Type:* boolean

replica-labels.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.query.replica-labels`
Labels to treat as a replica indicator along which data is
deduplicated.

Still you will be able to query without deduplication using
'dedup=false' parameter. Data includes time series, recording
rules, and alerting rules.

timeout.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.query.timeout`
Maximum time to process query by query node.

Defaults to `2m` in Thanos
when set to `null`.

### option `services.thanos.query.selector-labels`
Query selector labels that will be exposed in info endpoint.


*Type:* attribute set of string

response-timeout.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.store.response-timeout`
If a Store doesn't send any data in this specified duration then a
Store will be ignored and partial data will be returned if it's
enabled. `0` disables timeout.

Defaults to `0ms` in Thanos
when set to `null`.


*Type:* null or string

### option `services.thanos.query.store.sd-dns-interval`
Interval between DNS resolutions.

Defaults to `30s` in Thanos
when set to `null`.


*Type:* null or string

sd-files.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.store.sd-files`
Path to files that contain addresses of store API servers. The path
can be a glob pattern.


*Type:* list of string

sd-interval.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.store.sd-interval`
Refresh interval to re-read file SD files. It is used as a resync fallback.

Defaults to `5m` in Thanos
when set to `null`.


*Type:* null or string

unhealthy-timeout.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.store.unhealthy-timeout`
Timeout before an unhealthy store is cleaned from the store UI page.

when set to `null`.

config.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.tracing.config`
Tracing configuration.

When not `null` the attribute set gets converted to
a YAML file and stored in the Nix store. The option
{option}`tracing.config-file` will default to its path.

If {option}`tracing.config-file` is set this option has no effect.

See format details: <https://thanos.io/tip/thanos/tracing.md/#configuration>


*Type:* null or (attribute set)

config-file.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.tracing.config-file`
Path to YAML file that contains tracing configuration.

See format details: <https://thanos.io/tip/thanos/tracing.md/#configuration>


*Type:* null or string

external-prefix.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.web.external-prefix`
Static prefix for all HTML links and redirect URLs in the UI query web
interface.

Actual endpoints are still served on / or the
{option}`web.route-prefix`. This allows thanos UI to be served
behind a reverse proxy that strips a URL sub-path.


*Type:* null or string

prefix-header.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.web.prefix-header`
Name of HTTP request header used for dynamic prefixing of UI links and
redirects.

This option is ignored if the option
`web.external-prefix` is set.

Security risk: enable this option only if a reverse proxy in front of
thanos is resetting the header.

The setting `web.prefix-header="X-Forwarded-Prefix"`
can be useful, for example, if Thanos UI is served via Traefik reverse
proxy with `PathPrefixStrip` option enabled, which
sends the stripped prefix value in `X-Forwarded-Prefix`
header. This allows thanos UI to be served on a sub-path.


*Type:* null or string

route-prefix.description:
### option `services.thanos.query.web.route-prefix`
Prefix for API and UI endpoints.

This allows thanos UI to be served on a sub-path. This option is
analogous to {option}`web.route-prefix` of Promethus.


*Type:* null or string

### option `services.thanos.rule.alertmanagers.urls`

`dns+` or `dnssrv+` to detect
Alertmanager IPs through respective DNS lookups. The port defaults to
`9093` or the SRV record's value. The URL path is
used as a prefix for the regular Alertmanager API path.

max-time.description:
### option `services.thanos.store.max-time`
End of time range limit to serve.

Thanos Store serves only blocks, which happened earlier than this
value. Option can be a constant time in RFC3339 format or time duration
relative to current time, such as -1d or 2h45m. Valid duration units are
ms, s, m, h, d, w, y.

Defaults to `9999-12-31T23:59:59Z` in Thanos
when set to `null`.


*Type:* null or string

min-time.description:
### option `services.thanos.store.min-time`
Start of time range limit to serve.

Thanos Store serves only metrics, which happened later than this
value. Option can be a constant time in RFC3339 format or time duration
relative to current time, such as -1d or 2h45m. Valid duration units are
ms, s, m, h, d, w, y.

Defaults to `0000-01-01T00:00:00Z` in Thanos
when set to `null`.


*Type:* null or string

{option}`objstore.config-file` will default to its path.

when set to `null`.

request-samples.description:
### option `services.thanos.store.store.limits.request-samples`
The maximum samples allowed for a single Series request.
The Series call fails if this limit is exceeded.

`0` means no limit.

NOTE: For efficiency the limit is internally implemented as 'chunks limit'
considering each chunk contains a maximum of 120 samples.

when set to `null`.

Check the thinkfan(1) manpage for available arguments.

fans.description:
### option `services.thinkfan.fans`
List of fans thinkfan will control.

::: {.note}
This section slightly departs from the thinkfan.conf syntax.
The type and path must be specified like this:
```
  type = "tpacpi";
  query = "/proc/acpi/ibm/fan";
```
instead of a single declaration like:
```
  - tpacpi: /proc/acpi/ibm/fan
```
:::



*Type:* list of (attribute set of (YAML value))

levels.description:
### option `services.thinkfan.levels`
[LEVEL LOW HIGH]

LEVEL is the fan level to use: it can be an integer (0-7 with thinkpad_acpi),
"level auto" (to keep the default firmware behavior), "level full-speed" or
"level disengaged" (to run the fan as fast as possible).
LOW is the temperature at which to step down to the previous level.
HIGH is the temperature at which to step up to the next level.
All numbers are integers.


*Type:* list of (tuple of (unsigned integer, meaning >=0, or one of "level auto", "level full-speed", "level disengaged") (unsigned integer, meaning >=0) (unsigned integer, meaning >=0))

sensors.description:
### option `services.thinkfan.sensors`
List of temperature sensors thinkfan will monitor.

::: {.note}
This section slightly departs from the thinkfan.conf syntax.
The type and path must be specified like this:
```
  type = "tpacpi";
  query = "/proc/acpi/ibm/thermal";
```
instead of a single declaration like:
```
  - tpacpi: /proc/acpi/ibm/thermal
```
:::



*Type:* list of (attribute set of (YAML value))

addresses.description:
### option `services.tigerbeetle.addresses`
The addresses of all replicas in the cluster.
This should be a list of IPv4/IPv6 addresses with port numbers.
Either the address or port number (but not both) may be omitted, in which case a default of 127.0.0.1 or 3001 will be used.
The first address in the list corresponds to the address for replica 0, the second address for replica 1, and so on.

clusterId.description:
### option `services.tigerbeetle.clusterId`

Since Nix only supports integers up to 64 bits, you need to pass a string to this if the cluster ID can't fit in 64 bits.
Otherwise, you can pass the cluster ID as either an integer or a string.


*Type:* unsigned integer, meaning >=0, or string matching the pattern [0-9]+

role.description:
### option `services.tor.relay.role`
Your role in Tor network. There're several options:

- `exit`:
  An exit relay. This allows Tor users to access regular
  Internet services through your public IP.

  You can specify which services Tor users may access via
  your exit relay using {option}`settings.ExitPolicy` option.

- `relay`:
  Regular relay. This allows Tor users to relay onion
  traffic to other Tor nodes, but not to public
  Internet.

  See
  <https://www.torproject.org/docs/tor-doc-relay.html.en>
  for more info.

- `bridge`:
  Regular bridge. Works like a regular relay, but
  doesn't list you in the public relay directory and
  hides your Tor node behind obfs4proxy.

  Using this option will make Tor advertise your bridge
  to users through various mechanisms like
  <https://bridges.torproject.org/>, though.

  See <https://www.torproject.org/docs/bridges.html.en>
  for more info.

- `private-bridge`:
  Private bridge. Works like regular bridge, but does
  not advertise your node in any way.

  Using this role means that you won't contribute to Tor
  network in any way unless you advertise your node
  yourself in some way.

  Use this if you want to run a private bridge, for
  example because you'll give out your bridge addr
  manually to your friends.

  Switching to this role after measurable time in
  "bridge" role is pretty useless as some Tor users
  would have learned about your node already. In the
  latter case you can still change
  {option}`port` option.

  See <https://www.torproject.org/docs/bridges.html.en>
  for more info.

::: {.important}
Running an exit relay may expose you to abuse
complaints. See
<https://www.torproject.org/faq.html.en#ExitPolicies>
for more info.
:::

::: {.important}
Note that some misconfigured and/or disrespectful
towards privacy sites will block you even if your
relay is not an exit relay. That is, just being listed
in a public relay directory can have unwanted
consequences.

Which means you might not want to use
this role if you browse public Internet from the same
network as your relay, unless you want to write
e-mails to those sites (you should!).
:::

::: {.important}
WARNING: THE FOLLOWING PARAGRAPH IS NOT LEGAL ADVICE.
Consult with your lawyer when in doubt.

The `bridge` role should be safe to use in most situations
(unless the act of forwarding traffic for others is
a punishable offence under your local laws, which
would be pretty insane as it would make ISP illegal).
:::


*Type:* one of "exit", "relay", "bridge", "private-bridge"

Whether to enable Traefik web server.

environmentFiles.description:

Files to load as environment file. Environment variables from this file
will be substituted into the static configuration file using envsubst.


*Type:* list of path

Set the group that traefik runs under.
For the docker backend this needs to be set to `docker` instead.


*Type:* string

The traefik package to use.

*Type:* package

staticConfigFile.description:
